537.02
Criminal mischief - see GEN. OFF.
541.04
 
553.01 OBSTRUCTING STREETS BY RAILROAD COMPANIES.
   (a)   (1)   No railroad company shall obstruct or permit or cause to be
obstructed a public street, road or highway by permitting a railroad car,
locomotive or other obstruction to remain upon or across it for longer than
five minutes to the hindrance or inconvenience of travelers or a person passing
along or upon such street, road or highway.
      (2)   At the end of each five minute period of obstruction of a public
street, road or highway, each railroad company shall cause such railroad car,
locomotive or other obstruction to be removed for sufficient time, not less
than three minutes, to allow the passage of persons and vehicles waiting to
cross.
      (3)   This section does not apply to obstruction of a public street, road
or highway by a continuously moving through train or caused by circumstances
wholly beyond the control of the railroad company, but does apply to other
obstructions, including without limitation those caused by stopped trains and
trains engaged in switching, loading or unloading operations.
      (4)   If a railroad car, locomotive, or other obstruction is obstructing
a public street, road, or highway in violation of subsection (a)(1) hereof and
the violation occurs in the unincorporated area of one or more counties, or in
one or more municipal corporations, the officers and employees of each affected
county or municipal corporation may charge the railroad company with only one
violation of the law arising from the same facts and circumstances and the same
act.
      (5)   Upon the filing of an affidavit or complaint for violation of this
subsection (a)(1) hereof, summons shall be issued to the railroad company
pursuant to Ohio R.C. 2935.10(B), which summons shall be served on the regular
ticket or freight agent of the company in the county where the offense
occurred.
(ORC 5589.21)
   (b)   For purposes of this section, "railroad company" includes the
officers, employees and agents of such company.
   (c)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first
degree and shall be fined one thousand dollars ($1,000).
553.011 OBSTRUCTING STREETS BY ABANDONING THE LOCOMOTIVE.
   (a)   No railroad company shall obstruct, or permit or cause to be
obstructed, a public street, road, or highway, by permitting any part of a
train whose crew has abandoned the locomotive to remain across it for longer
than five minutes to the hindrance or inconvenience of travelers or a person
passing along or upon the street, road, or highway, unless the safety of the
train crew requires them to abandon the locomotive.
   (b)   Upon the filing of an affidavit or complaint for violation of this
section, summons shall be issued to the railroad company pursuant to Ohio R.C.
2935.10(B), which summons shall be served on the regular ticket or freight
agent of the company in the county where the offense occurred.
(ORC 5589.211)
   (c)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first
degree and shall be fined five thousand dollars ($5,000).
(ORC 5589.99)
553.02 CLIMBING UPON RAILROAD CARS.
   (a)   No person shall climb, jump, step or stand upon or cling or attach
himself to a locomotive, engine or car upon the track of a railroad, unless in
compliance with law or by permission under the rules of the corporation
managing such railroad.
   (b)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
(ORC 4999.02)
553.03 DUTIES OF LOCOMOTIVE ENGINEER.
   (a)   No person in charge of a locomotive shall fail to bring the locomotive
to a full stop at least 200 feet before arriving at a crossing with another
track, or proceed through the crossing before signaled to do so or before the
way is clear.
   (b)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth
degree. If violation of this misdemeanor causes physical harm to any person,
whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree.
(ORC 4999.04)
553.04 RAILROAD VANDALISM.
   (a)   No person shall knowingly, and by any means, drop or throw any object
at, onto, or in the path of, any railroad rail, railroad track, locomotive,
engine, railroad car, or other vehicle of a railroad company while such vehicle
is on a railroad track.
   (b)   No person, without privilege to do so, shall climb upon or into any
locomotive, engine, railroad car, or other vehicle of a railroad company when
it is on a railroad track.
   (c)   No person, without privilege to do so, shall disrupt, delay, or
prevent the operation of any train or other vehicle of a railroad company while
such vehicle is on a railroad track.
   (d)   Whoever violates subsection (a) of this section is guilty of railroad
vandalism. Whoever violates subsection (b) of this section is guilty of
criminal trespass on a locomotive, engine, railroad car or other railroad
vehicle. Whoever violates subsection (c) of this section is guilty of
interference with the operation of a train.
   Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, railroad vandalism;
criminal trespass on a locomotive, engine, railroad car, or other railroad
vehicle; and interference with the operation of a train each is a misdemeanor
of the first degree. If the violation of subsection (a), (b) or (c) of this
section causes serious physical harm to property, creates a substantial risk of
physical harm to any person, causes physical harm to any person, or serious
physical harm to any person, the violation is a felony and shall be prosecuted
under appropriate State law.
   (e)   No person shall knowingly deface, damage, obstruct, remove, or
otherwise impair the operation of any railroad grade crossing warning signal or
other protective device, including any gate, bell, light, crossbuck, stop sign,
yield sign, advance warning sign, or advance pavement
marking.
   (f)   Whoever violates subsection (e) of this section is guilty of railroad
grade crossing device vandalism. Except as otherwise provided in this division,
railroad grade crossing device vandalism is a misdemeanor of the first degree.
If the violation of subsection (e) of this section causes serious physical harm
to property or creates a substantial risk of physical harm to any person,
causes physical harm to any person, or causes serious physical harm to any
person, railroad grade crossing device vandalism is a felony to be prosecuted
under appropriate state law.
(ORC 2909.10, 2909.101)
553.05 GRADE CROSSING DEVICE VANDALISM.
   (a)   No person shall knowingly deface, damage, obstruct, remove or
otherwise impair the operation of any railroad grade crossing warning signal or
other protective device, including any gate, bell, light, crossbuck, stop sign,
yield sign, advance warning sign, or advance pavement marking.
   (b)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of railroad grade crossing
device vandalism. Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, railroad
grade crossing device vandalism is a misdemeanor of the first degree. If the
violation of this section causes serious physical harm to property, creates a
substantial risk of physical harm to any person, causes physical harm to any
person, or causes serious physical harm to any person, railroad grade crossing
device vandalism is a felony and shall be prosecuted under appropriate State
law.
(ORC 2909.101)
553.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
501.99 for penalties applicable to any misdemeanor classification.)
CHAPTER 557
Minor's Curfew
557.01    Definitions.
557.02   Curfew hours.
557.03   Exceptions.
557.04   Parental responsibility.
557.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Disturbing the peace - see GEN. OFF.
509.03
Sale of tobacco to minors prohibited - see GEN. OFF.
521.11
Trespassing - see GEN. OFF.
541.05
 
557.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and
their derivations have the meaning given herein.
   (a)    "Minor" means any person under the age of eighteen years.
   (b)    "Parent" means any person having legal custody of a minor:
      (1)    As a natural or adoptive parent,
      (2)    As a legal guardian,
      (3)    As a person who stands in loco parentis, or
      (4)    As a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of
court.
   (c)    "Public place" means any street, highway, alley or right of way, to
include sidewalks; any park, playground, ground, place or building open to the
public; any privately or publicly owned place of amusement, entertainment, or
public accommodation, to include parking lots and other areas adjacent thereto;
and any vacant lot or land or, without the consent of the owner, any private
property.
   (d)    "Time of night" referred to herein, is based upon the prevailing
standard of time, generally observed at that hour by the public in the
Municipality, prima facie the time then observed in the Municipal
Administrative Offices and Police Station.
   (e)    "Year of age" continues from one birthday, such as the seventeenth
to, but not including the day of the next, such as the eighteenth birthday,
making it clear that seventeen or less years of age is herein treated as
equivalent to the phrase "under eighteen years of age". Similarly, for example,
eleven or less years of age means under twelve years of age. ( Ord. 900417-42.
Passed 5-1-90.)
557.02 CURFEW HOURS.
   (a)    No person seventeen or less years of age shall be in or upon any
public place during the period ending at 6:00 a.m. and beginning:
      (1)    At 10:00 p.m. for minors fifteen or less years of age; and
      (2)    At 12:00 a.m. for minors sixteen or more years of age.
   Such provisions of law shall be in effect daily except Friday and Saturday
when such curfew hours shall begin:
      (1)    At 11:00 p.m. for minors fifteen or less years of age; and
      (2)    At 1:00 a.m. for minors sixteen or more years of age.
   (b)    Any minor violating the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of
an act of unruliness and shall be cited to the County Juvenile Court.
(Ord. 900417-42. Passed 5-1-90.)
557.03 EXCEPTIONS.
   In the following exceptional cases, a minor in or upon a public place during
the nocturnal hours for which Section
557.02 is intended to provide the maximum limits of regulation shall not be
considered in violation of this chapter:
   (a)    When accompanied by a parent of such minor.
   (b)    When accompanied by an adult authorized by a parent of such minor to
take the parent's place in accompanying the minor for a designated period of
time and purpose within a specified area.
   (c)    When exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States
Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech and the
right of assembly. Such minor shall evidence the bona fides of such exercise by
first delivering to the Police Department written communication signed by such
minor and countersigned if practicable by a parent of such minor with their
home address and telephone number, addressed to the Police Chief, specifying
when, where and in what matter the minor will be in a public place at night
during the hours when this chapter is otherwise applicable to the minor, in the
exercise of a First Amendment right specified in such communication.
   (d)    In case of reasonable necessity, but only after such minor's parent
has communicated to the Police Department personnel the facts establishing such
reasonable necessity and designating the minor's proposed location, route,
purpose and the period of time the minor will be in or upon a public place.
   (e)    When the minor is on the sidewalk of the place where such minor
resides, or on the sidewalk of either next-door neighbor not communicating an
objection to the police officer.
   (f)    When returning home by a direct route from, and within thirty minutes
of, the termination of a school activity, or an activity of a religious or
other voluntary association or which prior notice, indicating the place and
probable time of termination, has been given in writing to and duly filed for
immediate reference by, the Chief of Police or the officer assigned by him on
duty at the Police Station.
   (g)    When authorized by special permit from the Mayor, carried on the
person of the minor, when necessary nighttime activities of a minor may be
inadequately provided for by other provisions of this chapter. A written
application shall be given to the Mayor, signed by a minor and by a parent of
such minor, if feasible, stating:
      (1)    The name, age and address of such minor;
      (2)    The name, address and telephone number of a parent thereof;
      (3)    The height, weight, sex, color of eyes and hair and other physical
characteristics of such minor;
      (4)    The necessity which requires such minor be in or upon a public
place during the curfew hours otherwise applicable; and
      (5)    The street or route and the beginning and ending of the period of
time involved by date and hour.
The Mayor may grant a permit in writing for the use by the minor of those
public places at such hours as in the Mayor's opinion may reasonably be
necessary. In an emergency, this may be handled by telephone, or other
effective communication, with a corresponding record being made
contemporaneously, either to the Mayor, or if unavailable, to the Police Chief.
   (h)    When authorized by regulation issued by the Mayor, in other similar
cases of reasonable necessity, similarly handled but adapted to necessary
night-time activities of more minors than can readily be dealt with on an
individual special permit basis. Normally such regulation by the Mayor
permitting use of public places should be issued sufficiently in advance to
permit appropriate publicity through news media and through other agencies such
as the schools, and shall define the activity, the scope of the use of public
places permitted, and the period of time involved not to extend more than
thirty minutes beyond the time for termination of such activity.
   (i)    When the minor carries a certified card of employment, briefly
identifying the minor, the address of his home and place of employment and his
hours of employment.
(Ord. 900417-42. Passed 5-1-90.)
557.04 PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY.
   (a)    No parent having legal custody of a minor shall knowingly permit or
by inefficient control allow such minor to be in or upon any public place under
circumstances not constituting an exception to, or otherwise beyond the scope
of this chapter. "Knowingly" includes knowledge which a parent should
reasonably be expected to have concerning the whereabouts of a minor in that
parent's legal custody. It is intended to continue to keep neglectful or
careless parents up to a reasonable community standard of parental
responsibility through an objective test. It shall, a fortiori, be no defense
that a parent was completely indifferent to the activities or conduct or
whereabouts of such minor.
   (b)   It shall be an affirmative defense to this section that such parent
has within thirty days preceding the alleged violation filed or caused to be
filed a complaint against such minor under Ohio R.C. 2151.27.
   (c)   A parent who violates this section is guilty of a minor misdemeanor
for the first offense and a misdemeanor of the fourth degree for each
subsequent offense.
(Ord. 900417-42. Passed 5-1-90.)
557.99 PENALTY.
   All minors found in violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be
taken to the City Hall and parents, guardians or persons in loco parentis shall
be notified to come to the City Hall and take personal charge of such minors.
The minor shall be released only to such parent, guardian or persons in loco
parentis, or to the juvenile authorities. Any minor found in violation of this
chapter who has once been held by the authorities for violation of this chapter
shall be held for juvenile authorities for proper disposition.
(Ord. 900417-42. Passed 5-1-90.)
CHAPTER 559
Skate Park Rules and Regulations
559.01   Skate park regulations.
 
559.01 SKATE PARK REGULATIONS.
   (a)   No person shall knowingly do any of the following:
      (1)   Enter onto any skate park pad or use any skate park apparatus with
any device, motorized or otherwise, with the exception of in-line skates or
skateboards.
      (2)   Engage in conduct or create a condition that presents a risk of
physical harm to the offender or another, or the property of another.
      (3)   Fail to abide by any posted rule or regulation promulgated by the
Salem Park Commission and posted at or around any skate park facility.
   (b)   Definitions:
      (1)   Skate Park Pad for the purposes of this section shall be defined as
all of the area comprised of the concrete, paved or other hard packed surface
upon which the skate park apparatuses sit or are otherwise affixed.
      (2)   Skate Park Apparatus shall be defined as any natural or constructed
object sitting on or affixed to a Skate Park Pad.
   (c)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of failing to abide by Skate
Park Rules and Regulations and is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. Any person who
violates this section and who is a minor, shall be subject to confiscation of
any such device, motorized or otherwise, with the exception of in-line skates
or skateboards that is brought onto or used on the skate park pad or apparatus
of any skate park facility with such property being returned to the parent or
legal guardian of the minor upon their request.
   (d)   Subsequent violations of this section within a twelve month period, or
any instance where the actions of the offender caused physical harm to another
or another’s property, shall result in a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
(Ord. 011204-73. Passed 12-4-01.)

CHAPTER 701
Ambulance Services
701.00       Definitions and terminology.
701.01   Certification standards.
701.02   Requirements.

701.04   Procedure for dispatching.

331.20

333.06
Pedestrian to yield to - see TRAF.
371.08
False reports - see GEN. OFF.
509.07
 
701.00 DEFINITIONS AND TERMINOLOGY.
   (a)    “Advanced Life Support (ALS)" - advanced medical treatment performed
by an EMT-P and/or EMT-I in accordance with local medical control protocols.
   (b)    "Basic Life Support (BLS)" - medical treatment performed by an EMT-
B or EMT-I in accordance with local medical control protocols.
   (c)    "Emergency Medical Technician Basic (EMT-B)" - a person who holds a
current certification to practice as an EMT-B under Section 4765.30 of the Ohio
Revised Code.
   (d)    "Emergency Medical Technician Intermediate (EMT-I)" - a person who
holds a current certification to practice as an EMT-I under Section 4765.30 of
the Ohio Revised Code.
   (e)    "Emergency Medical Technician Paramedic (EMT-P)" - a person who holds
a current certification to practice as an EMT-P under Section 4765.30 of the
Ohio Revised Code.
   (f)    "Ambulance" - any motor vehicle that is designed to be used for the
purpose of responding to emergency medical situations, transporting emergency
patients, and/or administering emergency medical care to patients before,
during, or after transportation from the scene of an emergency incident.
   (g)    "Private Ambulance Company or Service" - any non-public organization
whose primary purpose is to provide transportation and/or treatment of
emergency medical patients.
   (h)    "City" - as referred to in this Chapter city shall be the City of
Salem, Ohio.
   (i)    "Code 1" - a patient that has been determined by on scene evaluation
as to not needing an ambulance transport. Whereas the patient's condition is
that they can safely be moved by private automobile.
   (j)    "Code 2" - a response by an emergency vehicle to an emergency scene
and/or transport of an emergency medical patient that is not urgent enough to
constitute the use of emergency lights and siren, either to or from the scene.
   (k)    "Code 3" - a response by an emergency vehicle to an emergency scene
and/or transport of an emergency medical patient that is considered urgent
enough to warrant the use of emergency lights and siren, either to or from the
scene.
(Ord. 230516-35. Passed 5-22-23.)
 
701.01  CERTIFICATION STANDARDS.
   (a)    Each ambulance company and each ambulance and its equipment doing
business in the City shall comply with the provisions of Section 4766.03 and
Section 4766.07 of the Ohio Revised Code and all rules and regulations
promulgated by the Ohio Ambulance Licensing Board.
   (b)    Any ambulance service desiring to provide service within the City
shall provide information to the City which will prove that has been certified
to provide ambulance service according to all specifications within these
standards.
(Ord. 230516-35. Passed 5-22-23.)
701.02 REQUIREMENTS.
   The Ambulance Review Board or anyone to whom they may designate may at
anytime require any ambulance company, ambulance, or driver to submit to an
inspection to verify compliance with these standards. The City may require
proof of state certification, licensing, insurance or other state standards.
(Ord. 230516-35. Passed 5-22-23.)
701.03  ROTATION SYSTEMS.
   (a)    The City of Salem shall use and maintain a call-by-call rotation
system for ambulance calls received by the City dispatch center. The call-by-
call rotation shall be limited to no more than three (3) separate and unrelated
private ambulance providers. For any emergency call originating through the
City of Salem or any of its departments, when the patient/caller does not
indicate an unsolicited "choice," the dispatcher shall contact the next
provider on the rotation list. If that provider is not available or cannot
arrive within the designated response time as set out hereafter in subsections
(b) and (c) of this Section, the dispatcher will contact the next provider in
the rotation. If this ambulance is also unavailable to respond as required by
this ordinance, the City may dispatch the City Fire Department Ambulance if
available. The dispatcher may use discretion to handle dropped calls or
necessary back up calls. The City dispatcher shall comply with the rotation
list, but in times of exceptional call volume requests, may use their
discretion to call any provider to ensure that proper emergency services are
dispatched.
      (1)   When an ambulance company participating in the ambulance rotation
system is called directly for a medical emergency by any client, consumer or
such other non-City dispatch or personnel for a life threatening emergency,
said ambulance company must notify the Salem Dispatch immediately and directly
for the purposes of dispatching first responders if said ambulance company's
response time will exceed five (5) minutes.
   (b)   Each ambulance company wishing to participate in the rotation system
to provide emergency medical and ambulance services to the citizens of the City
of Salem shall be required to have and maintain a physical building within the
Salem City Limits not later than thirty (30) days from the time in which this
section takes effect. Such building must conform to the standards as set out by
the Ohio Medical Transportation Board, the Ohio Pharmacy Board, the Ohio
Revised Code and all other relevant Fire and Building Codes as deemed necessary
by the State of Ohio or the City of Salem. The Ambulance Review Board shall
have discretion to grant an additional thirty (30) days for an ambulance
company to obtain a compliant building, or to bring a building into compliance,
after this section takes effect. The ambulance company must be licensed by the
State of Ohio, meet all statutory requirements as outlined in the Ohio Revised
Code and operate as advanced life support service under the Ohio Ambulance
Licensing Board (OALB). Each company wishing to be included in this rotation
must submit a copy of their current State of Ohio Ambulance License to the
Ambulance Review Board through the Director of Public Service and Safety. It is
the responsibility of each ambulance company to ensure that a current OALB
license is on file with the Ambulance Review Board. In order to qualify to
participate in the rotation, each providing ambulance company must have a
paramedic staff and an advanced life support equipped emergency unit. Such unit
must be capable of responding to emergency calls from the City dispatch within
nine (9) minutes of the call receipt to be on the scene.
        Anytime an ambulance company that is part of the current rotation does
not have a unit in the City, or has no units available due to other emergencies
or issues, they shall notify dispatch and go off of the rotation until a unit
returns to the City or they have units available in the City for immediate use.
   (c) An Ambulance Review Board is hereby created which shall consist of five
(5) persons and include, the Fire Chief, and the Director of Public Service and
Safety, a member of Council who is the Safety Committee Chairperson, an
individual not employed by the City of Salem as determined by a majority of the
previous three (3) members, and a City resident appointed by the Mayor. The
last two (2) members of the Board shall be confirmed by Council. No member of
the Board may have any personal or financial interest in any ambulance service
that is a part of the ambulance rotation. The Ambulance Review Board will
decide in their absolute discretion whether any ambulance provider shall be
listed on the City rotation list. In making this decision they will use the
applicant's service record and performance in this or other communities. Other
factors to consider are:
            (1)    Overall response time integrity.
      (2)    Percentage of time the company has not had ambulance available to
respond to calls initiated by government entities or medical facilities.
      (3)   The ability to place an ambulance on the scene of an emergency
(Code III) within nine (9) minutes or less, ninety percent (90%) of the time,
and the ability to place an ambulance on the scene of a non-emergency immediate
dispatch (Code II) within fifteen (15) minutes or less, ninety percent (90%) of
the time. The City understands that due to periods of inclement weather or
other hazardous road conditions that response times may be slightly longer. Due
to the safety of all personnel involved such occasions shall be noted as
excused exceptions by the Ambulance Review Board on a case by case basis.
           (4)    The number and types of Basic Life Support and Advanced Life
Support ambulances operated twenty-four (24) hours a day.
      (5)   Responsiveness to handling of complaints.
      (6)   Ability to provide computer generated response time reports.
      (7)   Willingness to participate in disaster planning.
      (8)   Willingness to provide "stand-by service" at community events.
      (9)   Ability and commitment to respond to community needs as demand for
service increases.
      (10)   Ability to retain for thirty (30) days voice recordings of all its
dispatch telephone lines and its two-way radio traffic.
      (11)   Whether the provider has a business location in the City.
      (12)   Any other relevant factor.
   (d)   The Ambulance Review Board shall at their discretion convene meetings
and adopt rules for their meetings that they deem necessary for the
administration of this section. Further, the Ambulance Review Board in addition
to determining what ambulance companies will be on the rotation, can demand
response times or other relevant information to determine that ambulance
companies are in compliance with this section. The Ambulance Review Board is
further empowered to remove an ambulance company from the rotation based upon
any or all of the factors listed in subsection (c) above.
   (e)   If a registered ambulance company, that is part of the current
rotation, is having a temporary issue with providing services, they may ask the
Ambulance Review Board for an exception to the ninety percent (90%) response
time for a time to be determined by the Ambulance Review Board, before being
removed from the rotation.
   (f)   Any grievance or issue that any ambulance service provider has with
regard to any paragraph or section associated with this ordinance shall first
address that grievance with the Ambulance Review Board by requesting a hearing
of that Board in writing delivered to the Salem Safety and Service Director at
his office in City Hall. Upon the receipt of any such request for hearing, the
Ambulance Review Board shall convene a hearing as soon as is practicable in
consideration of the schedules and availability of the members of the Board and
the party requesting the hearing. The Board shall in its sole discretion have
the authority to resolve the issue or grievance in whatever manner that they
believe accurately adheres to the requirements of this ordinance and is in the
best interest of the citizens of the City of Salem.
(Ord. 240220-11. Passed 3-12-24.)
701.04 PROCEDURE FOR DISPATCHING.
   (a)   It is in the best interest of the City of Salem to dispatch ambulance
services pursuant to emergency calls received by the City of Salem by the
police dispatch personnel.
   (b)   The Salem Police Chief, or personnel designated by him, will oversee
the dispatching of ambulance services pursuant to emergency calls received by
the City of Salem.
   (c)   The Police Chief, or the personnel designated by him, will dispatch
ambulance services pursuant to the rotation schedule of authorized ambulance
service providers as set out in this Code.
   (d)   All 911 dispatch personnel that receive an emergency medical call
requiring ambulance services will Tone the Salem Fire Department for EMS-
Personnel then dispatch an ambulance company to the emergency starting with the
ambulance company on rotation.
   (e)   The Salem Fire Department will relay any emergency calls that they
receive requiring ambulance services to the police dispatcher and shall respond
to the emergency as EMS-Personnel. In the event that any private ambulance
company dispatched as part of this rotation, or otherwise, does not respond
within the time allowance for the code classification set out herein, and the
Salem Fire Department ambulance is providing care, the Salem Fire Department
ambulance service may transport to the nearest appropriate hospital emergency
department. In addition, the Salem Fire Department ambulance personnel always
have the authority to make medically necessary on site judgment calls for the
health and safety of the Salem residents.
   (f)   Any ambulance service, public or private, who receives an emergency
medical call requiring ambulance services from anyone other than the City of
Salem Dispatch for response within the City of Salem shall notify the City of
Salem dispatcher who in turn will Tone the Salem Fire Department for EMS-
Personnel. Any ambulance service notifying the Salem Dispatch in accordance
with this section or an ambulance service dispatched by the City of Salem
pursuant to the call by call rotation or otherwise, shall immediately notify
the Salem Dispatch personnel as to whether or not they have a squad that is
immediately available to respond, and if no such squad is available, then the
Salem Dispatch will notify the City ambulance service on the rotation or the
closest known available squad possible to ensure a timely response.
(Ord. 230516-35. Passed 5-22-23.)
CHAPTER 705
Auctions
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 4707.01 et seq., the Ohio Department of
Commerce is now solely responsible for the licensing of auctioneers.
CHAPTER 709
Billiard and Poolrooms
709.01   License required.
709.02   License application.
709.03   License revocation.
709.04   License fees.
709.05   Disorderly conduct prohibited.
709.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.51, 715.61
Gambling - see GEN. OFF.
517.02 et seq.
 
709.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall open, conduct, operate or maintain a public place where
games of billiards or pool are permitted to be played or for the playing of
which games any compensation, direct or indirect, shall be demanded or paid,
unless the person shall first obtain a license therefor from the Housing,
Planning and Zoning Officer. The license shall be issued subject to the rules
and regulations set forth in this chapter but no license shall be granted to
any person under the age of twenty-one, or to any person not a citizen of the
United States.
(Ord. 970617-57. Passed 7-15-97.)
709.02 LICENSE APPLICATION.
   (a)   Every person desiring to open, conduct, operate or maintain a public
billiard room or poolroom shall file with the Housing, Planning and Zoning
Officer a written application stating his full name and address, or if more
than one person or an association or firm, the full names of all parties
interested and their addresses. If the applicant is a club, society or
corporation, the application shall contain a complete list of the officers,
their names and addresses, and the names and addresses of one or more persons
whom it desires to designate as manager or person in charge.
   (b)   The applicant shall also state the following:
      (1)   The premises and address where the poolroom is to be conducted, and
the number of tables proposed to be operated.
      (2)   The age of the applicant in case of individuals, and the ages of
the manager and officers in case of a club, society or corporation.
      (3)   Whether the applicant is a citizen of the United States.
      (4)   Whether the applicant has ever engaged in operating the kind of
business for which the license is sought, and when, where and how long in each
place within five years then last past.
      (5)   The name of the owner of the premises in which the business is to
be located and his complete address.
   (c)   The application shall be signed by the applicant, or in the case of a
club, society or corporation, by its manager or any of its officers.
(Ord. 970617-57. Passed 7-15-97.)
709.03 LICENSE REVOCATION.
   The Housing, Planning and Zoning Officer may revoke any license or suspend
it for not more than three months if the licensee is convicted of operating a
poolroom or billiard room in violation of any of the provisions of this
chapter. The Housing, Planning and Zoning Officer shall keep a record of all
licenses issued and shall pay over to the Treasurer all fees collected pursuant
to this chapter, who shall place them to the credit of the General Fund.
(Ord. 970617-57. Passed 7-15-97.)
709.04 LICENSE FEES.
   The fee for the license shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each
business location licensed. A further fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) shall be
charged for each pool table or billiard table operated in such business
locations during the year for which the license is granted. In case of poolroom
or billiard room combined, the annual license fee shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00) plus fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each pool table or billiard table.
(Ord. 970617-57. Passed 7-15-97.)
709.05 DISORDERLY CONDUCT PROHIBITED.
   Poolrooms and billiard rooms shall at all times be conducted in a quiet and
orderly manner.
709.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. Each day on which a violation occurs or continues shall be deemed
a separate offense.
CHAPTER 713
Bowling Alleys
713.01   Definitions.
713.02   License required.
713.03   Application for license.
713.04   License fees.
713.05   Investigation of applicant; appeal and hearing.
713.06   Issuance of license.
713.07   License nontransferable.
713.08   License to be posted.
713.09   License revocation.
713.10   Sanitary requirements.
713.11   Gambling prohibited.
713.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.51, 715.61
 
713.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings ascribed to them:
   (a)   “Bowling” means any of the several games played on a bowling alley, by
whatever name known.
   (b)   “Bowling alley” means any public room or place where the game of
bowling is permitted to be played.
(1956 Code Sec. 513.01.)
713.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, society, club, firm or corporation shall open, conduct, maintain
or operate a bowling alley within the City unless the person shall have been
licensed by the City.
(1956 Code Sec. 513.02)
713.03 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   (a)   Every person, society, club, firm or corporation desiring to open or
maintain a bowling alley must make application to the Housing, Planning and
Zoning Officer for a license therefor. Such application shall be in the form
prescribed by the Housing, Planning and Zoning Officer.
   (b)   No license shall be granted to a person who is not a citizen of the
United States.
   (c)   Every applicant for a license shall file with the Housing, Planning
and Zoning Officer, a written application stating the full name and address of
the applicant or firm, the full names of all parties interested, or if an
association or firm, the full names of all parties and their addresses. If the
applicant is a club, society or corporation, the applicant shall submit a
complete list of the officers of the club, society or corporation, with their
names and addresses, and shall also give the state in which the club, society
or corporation is organized and the names of one or more persons whom the club,
society or corporation desires to designate as its manager or managers, with
their addresses. The application shall also state the following:
      (1)   The premises where the bowling alley is to be conducted.
      (2)   Whether the applicant or manager is a citizen of the United States.
      (3)   Whether the applicant has ever been engaged in operating a bowling
alley and when, where and how long in each place operated within the past five
years.
      (4)   The name of the owner of the premises in which the bowling alley is
located and the complete address of the owner. The application shall be signed
by the applicant or applicants or in the case of a club, society or
corporation, the application shall be signed by the manager or any of the
officers.
(Ord. 970617-58. Passed 7-15-97.)
713.04 LICENSE FEES.
   The fee for the license shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each
business location. A further fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) shall be charged
for each bowling alley operated in each business location during the year for
which the license is granted.
(Ord. 970617-58. Passed 7-15-97.)
713.05 INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT; APPEAL AND HEARING.
   (a)   The Director of Public Service shall investigate the character of the
applicant or applicants or the officers of the club, society or corporation and
of the person who is to have general management of the business. The
application shall be rejected if the Director of Public Service finds that any
of the persons have previously been connected with any bowling alley where the
license has been revoked, or where any of the provisions of this chapter have
been violated, or if the bowling alley sought to be licensed does not comply in
every way with the regulations, ordinances and laws applicable thereto.
   (b)   If rejection of his application is made the applicant for license
shall be notified in writing to the reasons for rejection and shall have the
right to appeal to a board composed of the Mayor, Director of Public Safety and
the Director of Public Service. Such board shall have the power, after full
hearing, to confirm the rejection or order the license issued. In case of
appeal the applicant shall, within ten days after receiving notice of
rejection, perfect his appeal by leaving notice in writing of his intention to
appeal, at the office of the Mayor after the notice is filed with the Mayor.
(Ord. 970617-58. Passed 7-15-97.)
713.06  ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   The Housing, Planning and Zoning Officer shall issue a license pursuant to
the provisions of this chapter providing the license fees have been paid; that
he has received the information required by this chapter.
(Ord. 970617-58. Passed 7-15-97.)
713.07 LICENSE NONTRANSFERABLE.
   No transfer of a license either as to person or place shall be permitted
except with the consent of the Housing, Planning and Zoning Officer. Such
consent shall be endorsed upon the license; provided, further, the applicant
applying for the transfer of any license shall comply with all the provisions
of this chapter.
(Ord. 970617-58. Passed 7-15-97.)
713.08 LICENSE TO BE POSTED.
   Every licensee shall keep his license conspicuously posted in his bowling
alley.
(1956 Code Sec. 513.13)
713.09 LICENSE REVOCATION.
   (a)   The license for any bowling alley may be revoked by the Housing,
Planning and Zoning Officer for the violation of any of the rules, regulations,
ordinances and laws governing or applying to bowling alleys.
   (b)   Ten days before a license shall be revoked, the Housing, Planning and
Zoning Officer shall notify the licensee in writing of the reasons for the
proposed revocation and the licensee shall have the right to appeal to a board
composed of the Mayor, Director of Public Safety and the Director of Public
Service. Such board, after full hearing, shall have the power to revoke the
license or continue the same in force, and the action of this board shall be
final. In order to perfect his appeal, the licensee shall leave notice in
writing of his intention to appeal, at the office of the Mayor before the
expiration of ten days. Any license thus forfeited or revoked shall not be
granted to the same person, society, club, firm or corporation until at least
six months have elapsed from the time of the forfeiture or revocation of the
license.
(Ord. 970617-58. Passed 7-15-97.)
713.10  SANITARY REQUIREMENTS.
   All bowling alleys shall be kept in a clean, healthful and sanitary
condition. The Housing, Planning and Zoning Officer shall have the power to
determine if the rooms are so kept, and for this purpose shall, when desired,
have the assistance of the Fire Inspector.
(Ord. 970617-58. Passed 7-15-97.)
713.11 GAMBLING PROHIBITED.
   No form of gambling shall be permitted in any bowling alley or in the room
in which the alleys are located, or at any cigar stand or other business in the
same room, whether or not the room is divided by a partition nor shall any
checks be given which can be redeemed for merchandise or cash.
(1956 Code Sec. 513.10)
713.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. Each day on which a violation occurs or continues shall be deemed
a separate offense.

509.03
Gambling - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
517
Slugs - see GEN. OFF.
545.11
Tampering with coin machine - see GEN. OFF.
545.12
 
717.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm, association, club, society, or corporation shall operate,
conduct or maintain a public place where pinball machines and other coin
operated amusement devices excepting juke boxes or coin operated music devices
are permitted to be placed unless the person, firm, association, club, society
or corporation has first obtained a license from the Planning and Zoning
Officer. The license shall be issued subject to the rules and regulations set
forth in this chapter, but no license shall be granted to any person under the
age of twenty- one.
(Ord. 970218-11. Passed 3-18-97.)
717.02 FEE.
   The fee for the license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first
machine or device located upon each premises, and ten dollars ($10.00) for each
additional machine or device so located.
(Ord. 970218-11. Passed 3-18-97.)
717.03 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The Planning and Zoning Officer, within his discretion, may revoke any
license or suspend it for not more than thirty days if the licensee is
convicted of operating or maintaining such machines or devices in violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 970218-11. Passed 3-18-97.)
717.04 DISPOSITION OF FEES.
   The Planning and Zoning Officer shall keep a record of all licenses issued
and shall make payment of all fees collected therefor to the Treasurer, who
shall place them to the credit of the general fund.
(Ord. 970218-11. Passed 3-18-97.)
717.05 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm, association, club, society or corporation shall violate any
provision of this chapter.
(Ord. 691202-138. Passed 1-20-70.)
717.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provisions of this chapter shall be fined not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Each day’s violation shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 691202-138. Passed 1-20-70.)

CHAPTER 727
City Farm Market
727.01    Definitions.
727.02    Establishment.
727.03    Location.
727.04    Duration.
727.05    Documentation.
727.06    Regulations established.
727.07    Vending restrictions.
727.08    Exclusion from market.
727.09    Removal of garbage.
727.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "Farmers Market" means a location where producers congregate in a
temporary open air market to offer one or more of the following food items for
sale:
      (1)    Fresh unprocessed fruits or vegetables, and/or
      (2)    Products of a cottage food production operation as defined by Ohio
R.C. 3715.01.
   (b)    "Producer," for purposes of this chapter, means a person who raises
agricultural products on land owned or leased by themselves.
   (c)    A temporary open air market shall be defined as any retail or
wholesale vendor or vendors set up on a one time or recurring basis in any
space or location on City property not specifically under the control of any
City board or commission, that does not otherwise have a permanent structure
designed or permanently modified for retail or wholesale marketing purposes.
(Ord. 250218-12. Passed 2-18-25.)
727.02 ESTABLISHMENT.
   A special event Farmers Market shall be established for the sale of seasonal
produce, related products and plants. Said Market shall be open only to
producers of their own farm produce, plants and products. Organizations may
contract with the City of Salem for the purposes of coordinating a Farmers
Market subject to all rules and regulations of the Service and Safety Director,
City ordinances and applicable state laws.
(Ord. 250218-12. Passed 2-18-25.)
727.03 LOCATION.
   The location of a Farmers Market shall be subject to the approval of the
City Service and Safety Director in accordance with all local, state and
federal laws.
(Ord. 250218-12. Passed 2-18-25.)
727.04 DURATION.
   A Farmers Market may be held weekly at 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. from April 1
through October 30 of each calendar year subject to the approval of the City
Service and Safety Director.
(Ord. 250218-12. Passed 2-18-25.)
727.05 DOCUMENTATION.
   An organization responsible for coordinating a Farmers Market shall provide
to the City Service and Safety Director a list of vendors who will be
participating in a Farmers Market. The list shall contain the name, address,
and contact number of each producer or other vendor, products to be sold, dates
of participation in a Farmers Market and any other information required by the
City Service and Safety Director. Along with the above referenced list, the
City Service and Safety Director must be provided a copy of any required food
service licenses or other applicable licenses for each producer or other
vendor.
(Ord. 250218-12. Passed 2-18-25.)
727.06 REGULATIONS ESTABLISHED.
   Rules and regulations governing the operation of and participation in a
Farmers Market shall be established by the City Service and Safety Director and
shall be provided to vendors participating in a Farmers Market.
(Ord. 250218-12. Passed 2-18-25.)
727.07 VENDING RESTRICTIONS.
   (a)   A Farmers Market is limited to the sale of food and food products with
the exception of plants and flowers. Incidental services may be offered where
the vendor is participating as a "producer" as defined in this Chapter.
   (b)    Any item sold must meet all federal, state, county and local health
codes.
   (c)    No person shall purchase in a Farmers Market any produce or items for
the purpose of reselling the same again in the market or elsewhere in the City
during market hours.
(Ord. 250218-12. Passed 2-18-25.)
727.08  EXCLUSION FROM MARKET.
   The City Service and Safety Director, or his or her designee may prohibit
the participation of any producer or other vendor if there is an infraction of
the City Health Code, if there is any health, safety or welfare issue as
determined by the City Service and Safety Director or his or her designee, if
the vendor is selling products or articles expressly prohibited in this Chapter
or by regulation, or if the documentation required by this Chapter have not
been properly filed with the City Service and Safety Director.
(Ord. 250218-12. Passed 2-18-25.)
727.09 REMOVAL OF GARBAGE.
   No person shall bring onto or place into any trash receptacle of the City,
any garbage, litter or filth not associated with the immediate operation of an
authorized vendor's booth, stall or space at the Farmers Market. Failure to
remove the same to the extent that it accumulates at any market space assigned
to an authorized vendor may result in the immediate or future revocation of
authority to participate in the Farmers Market.
(Ord. 250218-12. Passed 2-18-25.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 729
Solicitors, Canvassers, Peddlers, Vendors, Transient Dealers
729.01    Purpose.
729.02    Definitions.
729.03    Door to door solicitation license required.
729.04    Notice prohibiting door to door solicitations.
729.05    Exceptions.
729.06    License required, fees.
729.07    Application.
729.08    Regulations and restrictions.
729.09    Distribution of handbills.
729.10    Appeals.
729.11    Enforcement.
729.12    Severability.
729.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.16
Home solicitation sales - see Ohio R.C. 1345.12 et seq.
Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. 2923.22
Sales of goods and services within right of way of Interstate and other State
highways - see Ohio R.C. 5515.07
Retail sales license - see Ohio R.C. 5739.17
729.01 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this section is to protect the public health, safety,
convenience, comfort, prosperity, or general welfare of the residents of the
City of Salem.
(Ord. 120515-38. Passed 6-5-12.)
729.02 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   Solicitor, Peddler or Canvasser means any person(s), firm,
partnership, corporation or other business desiring to sell, or carries with
him/her, goods, wares, merchandise, food products or services of any kind on
public or private property, door to door, within the corporate limits of the
City of Salem, rather than from a specific designated location and under the
provisions of this chapter. Peddler also means "hawker" or "huckster".
   (b)   Transient Dealers mean any person(s), firm, partnership, corporation
or other business desiring to "temporarily" open stores, places, sites or
locations on any private property within the Corporate limits of the City of
Salem, for six (6) months or less, for the purpose of selling goods, wares,
merchandise, food products or services of any kind and from a specific
designated location. A Transient Dealer shall not be construed to fall under
the classification of a vendor, solicitor or peddler whom solicits or sells
goods, wares, merchandise, food products or services of any kind through door
to door means rather than from a specific designated location.
   (c)    "Vendor", both stationary and mobile, means any person(s), firm,
partnership or corporation or other business engaged in the selling or offering
for sale, goods, wares, merchandise, services, food or beverages from a table,
bench, rack, wagon stand, cart, his/her person, motor vehicle or other device,
not within the confines of a building on private or public property, or right
of way within the corporate limits of the City of Salem. All Salem citizens and
private or public organizations, corporations, firms or partnerships living in
or located within the city limits of the City of Salem will be exempt from the
definition of Vendor for the purposes of sales made on their private property
for their personal or organizational profit during major community events.
   
   (d)   “Temporary place of business" means any public or private place
including, but not limited to, any storeroom, building or part of a building,
parking lot or vacant lot that is temporarily being occupied for the purpose of
making retail sales of goods, wares, merchandise, food products or services of
any kind, to the public. A place of business is not temporary if the same
person, firm partnership, corporation or other business conducted business at
the same place continuously for more than six (6) months or occupied the
premises as their permanent residence for more than six (6) months.
   
   (e)   "Major Community Event" means such events as the Salem Super Cruise,
International Festival, Family Fall Fun Day, Community Farm Market, Annual Arts
& Crafts in the Park, Service Club events i.e., Kiwanis Annual Antique Show and
any event so approved by the City of Salem.
   (f)   Charitable Organization means either of the following:
       (1)    Any organization having an office, branch or church located
within the City of Salem that is determined by the Internal Revenue Service to
be a tax exempt organization pursuant to section 501(c)(3) of the Internal
Revenue Code;
      (2)    Any benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, educational, humane,
scientific, public health, environmental conservation, civic, or eleemosynary
objective or any objective that benefits local law enforcement personnel,
firefighters, or other persons who protect the public safety.
         (Ord. 201006-40. Passed 11-4-20.)
729.03  DOOR TO DOOR SOLICITATION LICENSE REQUIRED.
    (a)    No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business or
activity as a door to door solicitor, peddler or canvasser within the City of
Salem unless they fall into one of the exceptions set out in Section
729.05.
(Ord. 201006-40. Passed 11-4-20.)
729.04 NOTICE PROHIBITING DOOR TO DOOR SOLICITATIONS.
   (a)   Notice by the owner(s) or occupant(s) of any residence or business of
the determination to refuse to receive any uninvited solicitor, peddler,
canvasser shall be given by displaying a card, decal or sign with the words no
less than three-fourth (3/4) inch in height, upon or near the main entrance
door to the residence or place of business, containing the words "No
Solicitors" or similar words to convey the intent that the property owner shall
refuse to receive any uninvited solicitor, peddler or canvasser
   (b)    No person shall go upon any premises and ring the door bell, rap on
any door, or create any sound or visual effect in any manner calculated to
attract the attention of any occupant of such residence or place of business
for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupants thereof and engaging
in canvassing, solicitation or peddling for profit or nonprofit or charitable
in defiance of a notice displayed pursuant to this section. Violation of this
section shall result in the revocation of the door to door solicitation license
issued to said violator.
(Ord. 120515-38. Passed 6-5-12.)
729.05 EXCEPTIONS.
   The following exceptions from Section
729.03  shall be permitted:
   (a)    Persons/organizations who comply with Section
729.02  (f)(1)(2)
         (1)   The provisions of this Section shall not apply to the incidental
solicitation and sale of merchandise by religious or charitable organizations
provided that such solicitation and sales are made by bona fide members or such
religious or charitable organizations. The burden of proof of exempt status
under this section shall be upon the person claiming such exempt status.
      (2)   Persons or businesses for profit, hired by religious or charitable
organizations shall not be exempt from the provisions of this chapter.
      (3)   Persons exempt under Section
729.05  (a) shall provide a copy of said proof of exempt status and register
the name and address of each person soliciting and the date(s) the solicitation
shall take place. In no case shall the registration certificate for said
solicitation be longer than thirty (30) days. The City of Salem shall provide
an identification card for each solicitor.
   
   (b)    Soliciting, peddling or canvassing under the age of eighteen (18)
years old for the purpose of school, church, scouting, or other youth related
programs. Persons soliciting only the purchase of or subscription for
newspapers having their principal sale or distribution in this municipality or
the county. Persons under the age of eighteen (18) years old shall not be used
as solicitors, peddlers or canvassers by, for profit business, in order to
circumvent the requirements of this chapter.
(Ord. 201006-40. Passed 11-4-20.)
729.06 LICENSE REQUIRED, FEES.
    (a)    No person or organization shall engage in business as a transient
dealer or vendor without first obtaining a license and paying a fee, from the
Salem City Planning and Zoning Office. Fees are not pro rated nor refundable
and the following fee schedule shall be established:
            (1)    For each door to door solicitor, peddler, canvasser shall be
four hundred dollars ($400.00) for the calendar year.
            (2)    Transient dealer: The license fee shall be one hundred fifty
dollars ($150.00). Said License shall expire six (6) months following the date
of issuance.
             (3)    Vendor: The license fee shall be one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00) and shall expire on December 31 of each year regardless of when
purchased.
         (Ord. 201006-40. Passed 11-4-20.)
729.07 APPLICATION.
     (a)   Applications for transient dealers and vendors shall be made upon a
form generated and provided by the Planning and Zoning Officer which shall
require, at least, the following information:
      (1)    The name of the applicant and physical description.
      (2)    The home address of the applicant and social security number.
      (3)    The current name and address of the person by whom the applicant
is employed, company name, address, telephone number(s) as well as the name of
the immediate superior.
      (4)    The length of applicant's service with such employer.
      (5)    All places of residence of the applicant and all employment during
the past year.
      (6)    The nature and character of goods to be sold or services to be
furnished by the applicant.
      (7)    The names of other municipalities in which the applicant has
recently conducted activities for which a license is herein required in
addition to any municipalities which the applicant has been denied a license or
had a license revoked with the reasons listed.
      (8)    Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of any crime , and
if so, the nature thereof, location and the penalty therefore.
      (9)    A current driver's license or state identification card.
      (10)    Motor vehicle make, model, year, current registration number and
license plate number.
      (11)    A current original color photograph of the applicant which shall
be 2 inches by 2 inches, showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a
clear and distinguishing manner.
      (12)   Completion and filing of an approved Municipal Income Tax
Registration Form.
   (b)   Applications for transient dealers and vendors shall be made at least
forty eight (48) hours before a license is issued.
   (c)   Upon receipt of the application for transient dealers and vendors, the
Planning and Zoning Officer shall cause such investigation of the applicant to
be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good.
   (d)    If, as a result of the investigation, based on Section
 729.07  (e)(1) through (6), and other regulations found in this chapter, the
application is found to be satisfactory or unsatisfactory, the Planning and
Zoning Officer shall endorse on the application his approval or disapproval. If
the Planning and Zoning Officer disapproves the applicant, he shall indicate
his reasons for the same and no licencee shall be issued.
   
   (e)   Such license may be refused to any person or revoked for, but not
limited to, the following reason(s):
      (1)    Failure to properly complete the application.
      (2)    Failure to pay the required fee.
      (3)    Failure to truthfully and completely give all information required
of the applicant.
      (4)    Conviction of a felony or crime of moral turpitude.
      (5)    Reason to believe that such person is a danger to persons or
property within the community.
      (6)    Failure to be in compliance with Section
729.04( b).
                  (Ord. 201006-40. Passed 11-4-20.)
729.08 REGULATIONS AND RESTRICTIONS.
   (a)    A mobile or stationary type vendor or other device for the sale of
food products/items as detailed in Section
 729.02 (c) are permitted at various locations on a city right-of-way or
parking lot with a required license per Section
 729.06 (a)(2).
   (b)    The permitted area of a stationary type vendor device shall consist
of:
      (1)    The west right-of-way of Ellsworth Avenue to the east right-of-way
of Lincoln Avenue and the north right-of-way line of East Second Street to the
south right-of-way line of Pershing Street. Included are city parking lots in
this general area..
      (2)    On private commercial/industrial property with the written
approval of the property or business owner and the required city license.
   (c)    The Director of Public Service and Safety shall determine the exact
location where said device shall be located on a city right-of-way or parking
lot and said device shall not be relocated with out permission.
   (d)    A stationary type vendor located on the sidewalk in a city right-of-
way shall not block the normal flow of pedestrian traffic and shall not be
located on the roadway (street surface) unless specifically authorized. In
addition, a stationary type vendor shall not be located within fifty (50) feet
of an establishment whose business sells the same product as the stationary
vendor.
   (e)    Permission is not granted to operate said devices within city
property under the direct control of the Salem Parks Department. In addition to
these regulations, if applicable, a separate permit shall be obtained from the
Salem Parks Department for operation within city property under direct control
of said department.
   (f)    In addition, vendors located on public or private property during any
Major Community Event shall be required to obtain a "spot" type license for
said event from the sponsoring organization. Stationary and mobile vendors who
only participate by obtaining a "spot" at a Major Community Event are exempt
from the requirements of this chapter with the exception of Income Tax
Department and Health Department Requirements. Said vendors shall be in
compliance with all requirements established by the sponsoring organization
including the payment of fees to the sponsoring organization.
   (g)    Each vendor device shall constitute a separate license.
   (h)    Once obtained, a vendor license shall be issued by the City of Salem
Zoning Office and said license shall be displayed on each device.
   (i)    For the sale of food products, a current Health Department
Certificate, in accordance with the Ohio Health Department Regulations shall be
displayed on each device.
   (j)    All advertising signs shall only be attached to the device and shall
not extend beyond the device.
   (k)    Each stationary type vendor device shall be self contained and shall
not be connected to an exterior/outside source of power/water unless the
stationary vendor has obtained a "spot" license for a Major Community Event
where exterior/outside electrical power/water is provided.
   (l)    The hours for a stationary type vendor device shall not be before 9:
00 a.m. and not after 9:00 p.m. and each device shall be removed from a city
right-of-way or parking lot/property at the close of business each day except
those stationary vendors who have obtained a "spot" license for a Major
Community Event.
   (m)    A stationary type vendor device shall not employ any sound amplifying
device and shall not employ any parts or elements which revolve, rotate, whirl
or spin to attract attention. Each device shall employ only light emitting a
light of constant intensity, and shall not be illuminated by or contain
flashing, intermittent, rotating, or moving lights or signs. In addition, a
lighting device shall not permit the beams to be directed upon a public
thoroughfare so to cause glare or reflection that may constitute a traffic
hazzard.
   (n)    Vendors who only conduct business operations on property under the
direction of the Salem Parks Department and/or at Major Community Events as
found in Section
729.02 (e), (f) are exempt from license requirements and fees, except Income
Tax and Health Department requirements.
   (o)    Vendors who are mobile and move about the streets using a motor
vehicle to sell ice cream, popsicle, ice sherbert, other frozen deserts, soft
drinks, candy, sandwiches, peanuts, popcorn shall comply with the following
regulations:
      (1)    Each vehicle shall first be inspected by the Salem City Police
Department as to the mechanical safety as well as to the proper warning and
safety lights
      (2)    The operator/owner of each vehicle shall be required to have
currently in-force commercial general liability insurance consisting of three
hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) each occurrence combined single limit
for bodily injury and property damage liability and list the City of Salem a
certificate holder. In addition, the owner/operator shall have a currently in-
force general vehicle insurance and valid operator's license for any operator.
      (3)    Day or night, yellow warning lights shall be operated continuously
when the vendor is stopped for sales and when the vehicle has slowed down to
five miles per hour or less for selling. Lights must be off when traveling to
and from route.
      (4)    Vendors shall display the city license on the window being used
for sales.
      (5)    No riders except those who are employees of the vendor shall be
allowed.
      (6)    Sales shall only be conducted from the right side of the vehicle.
Vendors shall not sell to customers unless they stay on the curb lawn or berm.
In no case shall the vehicle pull to the wrong side of the street to service
customers. Vendors must make sure that all children/customers are away from the
vehicle before driving away. Vendors shall act to protect children/customers at
all times especially from oncoming traffic.
      (7)    Vendors shall refrain from allowing boxes and papers to fall upon
the public right-of-way and shall pick up any papers deposited in the immediate
area of sale by their customers.
      (8)    Vendors shall not travel through and/or stop within the property
under the direct control of the Salem Parks Department unless given written
approval by said Parks Department
      (9)    Vendor hours shall not be before 9:00 a.m. and not after 9:00
p.m., or dusk, whichever comes first.
         (Ord. 120515-38. Passed 6-5-12.)
729.09 DISTRIBUTION OF HANDBILLS.
   (a)   No person shall deposit, place, throw, scatter, attach or cast any
handbill in or upon any public place within the city, and no person shall sell
any handbill in a public place. It shall not be unlawful to hand out or
distribute a handbill, without charge to the receiver thereof, any handbill in
a public place to any person willing to accept such handbill. Handbills shall
not be passed out or distributed within any city right-of-way.
   (b)   No person shall distribute, deposit, throw, scatter, attach or cast
any handbill in or upon any automobile or other vehicle. It shall not be
unlawful to hand, transmit or distribute any handbill to the owner or occupant
of any automobile or other vehicle who is willing to accept the same. Handbills
shall not be passed out or distributed within any city right-of-way.
   (c)   No person shall distribute, deposit, place throw, scatter, attached or
cast any handbill in or upon an private premises or vacant land which are
temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant.
   (d)   Persons may place or deposit any such handbill upon such inhabited
private premises, except those posted as "No Trespassing," "No Advertisements"
or any similar notice, if the handbill is so placed or deposited as to secure
or prevent the handbill from being blown or drifted about such premises or
elsewhere, except that mailboxes may not be so used when so prohibited by
Federal Postal Laws or Regulations.
   (e)    Persons placing or depositing handbills under section (d) shall not
go upon any private premises and ring the door bell or rap or knock on any door
or create any sound in any manner calculated to attract the attention of ay
occupant of such premises.
   (f)    Persons intending to place or deposit handbills upon any private
premises shall first be registered by the Zoning Office for the purpose of
receiving a copy of these regulations. There shall not be a fee for said
registration.
(Ord. 120515-38. Passed 6-5-12.)
729.10 APPEALS.
   Any applicant who has applied for a license in accordance with this chapter
and to whom the Planning and Zoning Officer has, after an investigation, denied
a license may appeal to Council. An appeal may be taken to Salem City Council
within five (5) days of the denial of the Planning and Zoning Officer by filing
with the Clerk of City Council a written notice of appeal and stating grounds
thereon. A non-refundable fee of Fifty (50) Dollars shall be paid to the City
of Salem for said appeal upon filing. Such appeal shall be heard by Council at
the next regular meeting and its decision shall be final.
(Ord. 120515-38. Passed 6-5-12.)
729.11 ENFORCEMENT.
   Enforcement of this chapter shall be the responsibility of the Salem
Planning and Zoning Division and Salem Police Department.
(Ord. 120515-38. Passed 6-5-12.)
729.12 SEVERABILITY.
   Should any section, provision, clause, phrase or sentence of this chapter be
declared by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, that decision
shall not effect the validity of this chapter as a whole or any part thereof,
other than the part so declared to be invalid.
(Ord. 120515-38. Passed 6-5-12.)
729.99 PENALTY.
      Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more
than two hundred dollars ($200.00) per violation per day. Each day on which
sales are conducted in violation of this chapter shall constitute a separate
offense.
(Ord. 201006-40. Passed 11-4-20.)
CHAPTER 733
Taxicabs and Transit Vehicles
 
733.01    Definitions.
733.02    Supervision and enforcement.
733.03    Taxicab operator and transient vehicle fee.
733.04    Insurance required.

733.09    Prohibited acts.
733.10    Driver license requirements.
733.11    Background check, denial of license.
