a person under the age of eighteen (18) years on the premises of a sexually
oriented business.
(Ord. 020219-15. Passed 2-20-02.)
739.19 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   No sexually oriented business shall be open for business before eight
o’clock (8:00) a.m., Monday-Saturday or after ten o’clock (10:00) p.m., Monday-
Saturday. A sexually oriented business shall be closed at all times on sundays
and legal, federal or state recognized holidays.
(Ord. 020219-15. Passed 2-20-02.)
739.20 VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   (a)   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a
minor misdemeanor. Each day’s failure to comply with any such provision shall
constitute a separate minor misdemeanor violation. Second or subsequent
violations of the same section of this chapter by an owner, his agent or an
employee, shall constitute a misdemeanor of the fourth degree requiring a
mandatory court appearance.
   (b)   The Law Director is hereby authorized and empowered in cases of
flagrant, continued and repeated violations of this chapter, to apply to a
court of competent jurisdiction for an order enjoining the owner, owners,
employee or employees from occupying, using, or conducting business at, through
or from any location where such violation or violations exist. Further, the
City may initiate a civil enforcement proceeding by Complaint or such other
means as provided by the Ohio Rules of Civil Procedure. Any person, partnership
or corporation who or which has violated any provision of this Chapter shall,
upon being found liable therefore in a civil enforcement proceeding commenced
by the City, pay a judgment of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for
each violation, plus all court costs and reasonable attorney fees incurred by
the City in the enforcement proceedings. In any case where a penalty for a
violation if this Chapter has not been timely paid and the person upon whom the
penalty was imposed is found to have been liable therefore in civil
proceedings, the violator shall be liable for the penalty imposed, including
additional daily penalties for continuing violations, plus court costs and
reasonable attorney fees incurred by the City in the enforcement proceedings. A
separate violation shall arise for each day or portion thereof in which a
violation is found to exist or for each section of the Chapter which is found
to have been violated. Additionally, the City shall be exempt from the payment
of costs in any civil case brought to enforce this chapter in accordance with
this paragraph. Further, the City may enforce any violation of this Chapter
through an equity action brought in the Court of Common Pleas of the county
where the City is situated.
(Ord. 020219-15. Passed 2-20-02.)
739.21 SEVERABILITY.
   The provisions of this Chapter are severable and if any section, subsection,
clause, sentence or part thereof shall be held or declared illegal, invalid,
and unconstitutional by any Court of competent jurisdiction, the decision shall
not affect or impair any of the remaining sections, subsections, clauses,
sentences or parts thereof, of this Chapter; it is hereby declared to be the
intent of the Salem City Council that this Chapter would have been adopted if
such illegal, invalid or unconstitutional section, subsection, clause, sentence
or part thereof had not been included herein.
(Ord. 020219-15. Passed 2-20-02.)
CHAPTER 741
Trash and Refuse Hauling
741.01    Definitions.
741.02   Private garbage disposal.
741.03   Containers required.
741.04   Marking of vehicles; loose loads prohibited.
741.05   Nuisance conditions prohibited.
741.06   Three or more family dwellings.
741.07   City trash and leaf pickup.
741.08   Compost piles.
741.09   License required for commercial hauler.
741.10   License issuance; term.
741.11   License fee.
741.12   Insurance required for commercial hauler.
741.13   Revocation and suspension of license.
741.14   Curbside recycling mandatory.
741.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Contracts with county garbage and rubbish disposal districts - see Ohio R.C.
343.08
Collection and disposal of garbage - see Ohio R.C. 715.43, 717.01
Employment of scavengers - see Ohio R.C. 3707.39
Disposal and transportation upon public ways - see Ohio R.C. 3767.20 et seq.
Vehicle loads dropping, sifting, leaking - see TRAF.
339.08
Littering - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
 
741.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following words shall have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them:
   (a)    "Garbage" means all waste or offal of fish, fowl, fruit, vegetable
and animal matter resulting from the preparation of food for human consumption,
from public and private establishments and from all residences.
   (b)    "Refuse" means all materials such as crockery, rags, old clothing,
wood, rubber and similar materials. It does not, however, include any material
in the nature of earth, sand, brush, stone, plaster or other substances that
may accumulate as a result of building operations, and it shall not include
paper, leaves, tree limbs and branches. Other refuse means all materials not
included in the foregoing description.
   (c)    "Satellite truck" means a truck picking up garbage and refuse for
transfer to a larger truck, which at no time is more than five minutes from the
satellite truck.
      (Ord. 671003-78. Passed 10-3-67; Ord. 730619-66. Passed 9-4-73.)
741.02 PRIVATE GARBAGE DISPOSAL.
   No person shall throw any garbage or refuse on the ground or bury the same
upon any premises, public or private or burn garbage or refuse outside.
(Ord. 671003-78. Passed 10-3-67; Ord. 730619-66. Passed 9-4-73.)
741.03 CONTAINERS REQUIRED.
   No family or person requiring the removal of garbage and refuse shall permit
the same to accumulate upon the premises except in covered containers approved
by the Housing, Planning and Zoning Officer. These shall be rust-resistant,
watertight, nonabsorbent and easily washable containers which are covered with
tightly fitting lids and have a handle or handles. Drums larger than ninety
gallons are not permissible for garbage storage. Plastic refuse bags properly
secured are also permissible. No garbage, refuse and debris may be placed on
the curbside for pickup longer than twenty-four hours.
(Ord. 051206-84. Passed 12-6-05.)
741.04 MARKING OF VEHICLES; LOOSE LOADS PROHIBITED.
   Vehicles of private garbage, trash and refuse haulers conveying garbage,
trash and refuse from residences or from business, commercial or industrial
enterprises, shall convey such substances in covered trucks or vehicles so
constructed as to prevent the leakage and scattering of the contents thereof.
Vehicles shall be clearly marked to identify the party licensed under this
chapter. This section applies to all vehicles with the exception of satellite
trucks.
(Ord. 840703-44. Passed 7-17-84.)
741.05 NUISANCE CONDITIONS PROHIBITED.
   (a)   Fermenting, putrefying or odorous garbage or other refuse in
containers other than containers described in Section
741.03 or dumped in the open is hereby declared to be a nuisance. The person
responsible for such nuisance shall be liable to prosecution according to law.
   (b)   Garbage shall not be permitted to accumulate under any conditions on
any property for more than seven days. Garbage shall not be permitted to
accumulate under any conditions in any vehicle over night.
(Ord. 671003-78. Passed 10-3-67; Ord. 730619-66. Passed 9-4-73.)
741.06 THREE OR MORE FAMILY DWELLINGS.
   In the case of a three or more family dwelling or a rooming house capable of
accommodating three or more roomers, the owner of the property shall be
responsible for the proper storage and disposal of garbage and refuse in
accordance with this chapter. In the case of condominium associations or three
or more units, the condominium association shall be responsible for the proper
storage and disposal of garbage and refuse in accordance with this chapter.
(Ord. 730619-66. Passed 9-4-73.)
741.07 CITY TRASH AND LEAF PICKUP.
   Residents or owners of property may place leaves or trash on the curb lawn
in anticipation of an announced pickup by the Service Department. Such
placement of leaves or trash on the curb lawn shall not take place more than
one week prior to the announced date or pickup by the Department for the
residence or property involved.
(Ord. 730619-66. Passed 9-4-73.)
741.08 COMPOST PILES.
   Properly maintained compost piles are not prohibited under this chapter
providing they do not contain any waste or offal of fish, fowl or animal
matter.
(Ord. 730619-66. Passed 9-4-73.)
741.09 LICENSE REQUIRED FOR COMMERCIAL HAULER.
   No person, firm or corporation shall collect, transport or dispose of
garbage and refuse for hire unless such person, firm or corporation has been
granted a license by the Housing, Planning and Zoning Officer.
(Ord. 970617-54. Passed 7-15-97.)
741.10 LICENSE ISSUANCE; TERM.
   The Housing, Planning and Zoning Officer shall grant a license to any
person, firm or corporation who applies for a license to collect, transport and
dispose of garbage and refuse within the City, provided such person, firm or
corporation meets the requirements of this chapter. This license shall be in
effect for a period of one year from January 1 to December 31 of each year.
(Ord. 970617-54. Passed 7-15-97.)
741.11 LICENSE FEE.
   A fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be paid to the Housing, Planning and
Zoning Officer before any license is granted under this chapter as the annual
fee or for any part of a year.
(Ord. 970617-54. Passed 7-15-97.)
741.12  INSURANCE REQUIRED FOR COMMERCIAL HAULER.
   Each hauler shall secure a policy of insurance, insuring against the
liability of such hauler in operating his motor equipment and in operations
other than those involving automotive exposure in the amount of one hundred
thousand dollars ($100,000) for personal injury for each accident, and for
twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000) property damage for each accident. The
policy shall be effective for a period of one year to coincide with the
effective period of the license granted under this chapter. Copies of all
insurance policies, endorsements thereto and receipts or other evidence of
payments of premiums shall be deposited by each commercial hauler with the
Housing, Planning and Zoning Officer.
(Ord. 970617-54. Passed 7-15-97.)
741.13 REVOCATION AND SUSPENSION OF LICENSE.
   The Housing, Planning and Zoning Officer may revoke or suspend any license
granted under this chapter for the failure of a hauler to comply with the
provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 970617-54. Passed 7-15-97.)
741.14 CURBSIDE RECYCLING MANDATORY.
   (a)    Each trash and refuse hauler licensed by the City under the
provisions of this chapter, must certify at the time of application for
licensing, as a prerequisite for such licensing, that the hauler offers a
program of curbside recycling to customers in Salem.
   (b)    Haulers licensed at the time of passage of this section shall provide
such certification within six months of the passage of this section, or upon
renewal of their license, whichever is earlier.
(Ord. 930504-56. Passed 5-18-93.)
741.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. Each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense.
CHAPTER 745
Emergency Alarms
745.01    Definitions.
745.02   Equipment regulation.
745.03   Permits required.
745.04   Issuance of permits.
745.05   Application forms.
745.06   Application, investigation and denial.
745.07   Appeal procedure.
745.08   Alarm business permit.
745.09   Alarm system permit.
745.10   Automatic dialing devices.
745.11   Alarms connected directly to police station.
745.12   Grounds for suspension and revocation.
745.13   Suspending and revoking authority.
745.14   Procedure.
745.15   Revocation.
745.16   Surrender of permit.
745.17   Exception.
745.18   False alarms.
745.19   Liability of City.
745.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
False alarms - see GEN. OFF.
509.07
 
745.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "Alarms business" means the business by any individual, partnership,
corporation, or other entity of: selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing,
repairing, altering, replacing, moving or installing any alarm system or
causing to be sold, leased, maintained, serviced, repaired, altered, replaced,
moved or installed any alarm system in or on any building, structure or
facility.
   (b)    "Alarm system" means any mechanical or electrical device which is
designed or used for the detection of an unauthorized entry into a building,
structure or facility or for alerting others of the commission of any unlawful
act within a building, structure or facility, or both; or for the detection of
fire, which emits a sound or transmits a signal or message when actuated. Alarm
systems include but are not limited to, direct dial telephone devices, audible
alarms and proprietor alarms. Devices which are not designated or used to
register alarms that are audible, visible or perceptible outside of the
protected building, structure or facility are not included with this
definition.
   (c)    "Alarm user" means any person, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company or organization of any kind who owns or leases an alarm
system as that term is described in subsection (b) hereof.
   (d)    "False alarm" means the activation of an alarm system through
mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation or the negligence of the
owner or lessee of an alarm system or of his employees or agents. Such
terminology does not include alarms caused by hurricanes, tornadoes,
earthquakes or other similarly violent conditions.
   (e)   "Issuing Authority" in the case of burglar alarm systems means the
Chief of Police, and in the case of fire alarm systems, means the Fire Chief of
the City.
(Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.02 EQUIPMENT REGULATION.
   (a)    All equipment used in installations for which a permit is required
under this chapter shall meet the applicable standards of the Underwriters
Laboratories and/or the National Fire Protection Association, and/or other
recognized industry standards. The applicant may be required to submit evidence
of the reliability and suitability of the equipment to be installed.
   (b)    All equipment, the use or installation of which is subject to this
chapter, shall be maintained in good operating condition. The Chief of Police
and/or Chief of Fire may require that repairs be made whenever he has
determined that such are necessary to assure proper operation.
(Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.03 PERMITS REQUIRED.
   (a)    Alarms Business. No person shall engage in, conduct or carry on, an
alarm business within the City without first applying for and receiving an
alarm business permit therefor in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter.
   (b)    Alarm System. No person shall possess or use an alarm system without
first applying for and receiving an alarm permit therefor in accordance with
the provisions of this chapter.
   (c)    User Registration Required.
      (1)    Every alarm user in the City shall register each alarm system in
use with the City Police Department.
      (2)    Each alarm user registering in accordance with the provisions of
this chapter shall provide the following information to the Police Department:
         A.    The name, address and telephone number of the protected
business, home or other location;
         B.    The name, address and telephone number of the alarm company
which installed or maintains the registrant's alarm system; and
         C.    In the case of a business entity, the names, addresses and
telephone numbers of three responsible employees of the business who can be
contacted by the Police Department if needed.
            (Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.04 ISSUANCE OF PERMITS.
   The Issuing Authority shall issue all permits for his respective Department.
(Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.05 APPLICATION FORMS,
   Applications for all permits required hereunder shall be filed with the
Issuing Authority and shall be accompanied by the requisite fee, if any. The
Issuing Authority shall prescribe the form of application and request such
information as is necessary to evaluate and act upon the application.
(Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.06 APPLICATION, INVESTIGATION AND DENIAL.
   (a)    Alarm Business. Every application for an alarm business shall require
a description of the alarm system offered for sale or lease to the public and a
description of any services relating to alarm devices offered to the public;
the name of the proprietor of the business; the names of the partners of the
business if it is a partnership; the names of the officers and principal
stockholders if it is a corporation; and the names of every employee of the
business who will engage in the business of installing, repairing, servicing,
selling, leasing or maintaining an alarm system. The Issuing Authority shall
conduct an appropriate investigation of the applicant to determine whether such
permit shall be issued. The Issuing Authority may require additional
information of applicants which he deems necessary to conduct his
investigation. The permit shall be denied by the Issuing Authority if:
      (1)    The character or reputation of the applicant, its partners,
officers, stockholders or employees is determined to be inimical to the safety
or general welfare of the community;
      (2)    The applicant does not comply with the standards and regulations
adopted pursuant to this chapter; or
      (3)    The applicant, his employee or agent has knowingly made any false,
misleading or fraudulent statement of a material fact in the application for a
permit.
   (b)    Alarm Systems. The permit shall be denied by the Issuing Authority if
the alarm system does not comply with the requirements of this chapter or in
the case of direct alarm systems is not compatible or cannot be made compatible
with the receiving system in use in the Police Department. A system must be
made compatible at the expense of the permittee. Such permit shall be issued to
the Alarm User.
(Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86)
745.07 APPEAL PROCEDURE.
   An applicant denied a permit may appeal within fifteen days of the denial to
the Appeal Board comprised of the Mayor, Director of Public Safety and Director
of Public Service, who shall hold a hearing thereon within fifteen days from
receipt of the notice of appeal. The Appeals Board may affirm or reverse the
denial of the permit.
(Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.08 ALARM BUSINESS PERMIT.
   An annual permit fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be due and
payable on July 1, 1986 and on July 1 of each subsequent year for each alarm
business doing business within the City. Such permit fee shall not be pro-
rated.
(Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.09 ALARM SYSTEM PERMIT.
   An annual permit shall be obtained by all Alarm Users. July 1 shall be the
anniversary date for all such permits. No fee shall be charged for the permit
except for automatic dialing devices as hereafter provided.
(Ord. 860608-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.10 AUTOMATIC DIALING DEVICES.
   (a)   The City may subscribe to one or more telephone lines for burglar or
robbery alarms, or for fire alarm purposes, or for similar purposes; and when
any line is so designated as provided for herein, persons may, upon proper
application and compliance with applicable laws, be granted a permit to install
a device or devices which automatically select the designated telephone line
for the purpose of playing a recorded message or to otherwise report an
intrusion or other emergency.
   (b)   No person shall use or cause to be used, for burglary or robbery, or
for fire alarm purposes, any telephone device or telephone attachment that
automatically selects any telephone line allocated by the telephone company to
the City or any of its departments or divisions, except a telephone line which
may be specifically designated by the Safety Director for such purpose. Such
designated telephone line or lines shall terminate at the Police Station
centers.
   (c)   For alarms of the type described herein, the message shall comply with
the following restrictions:
      (1)   Length of the message shall not exceed twenty seconds;
      (2)   The message shall not be repeated more than three times for each
dialing;
      (3)   Contents - the message shall first state: "This is a recording".
The balance of the message shall be appropriate to the purpose for which the
alarm is installed and shall be subject to approval of the Chief of Police and/
or the Chief of Fire. The entire message shall be intelligible.
   (d)   For alarms of the type herein described, each such device shall be
programmed to first dial the Police Station using an unlisted number assigned
for that purpose. The device shall next dial a number selected by the
applicant, such second number being that at which a person having a key to the
building where the alarm is installed can normally be found. A third number
subject to approval of the Chief of Police or the Chief of Fire may be
programmed for the next dialing. No more than three such dialings may be
programmed except upon approval by the Chief of Police or the Chief of Fire. No
enforcement agency other than the City Police may be selected.
   (e)   The cost of providing the service described above, including any fee
or payment charged by the telephone company, shall be paid by the applicant.
   (f)   The fee to be charged by the City shall be twenty dollars ($20.00) per
year per subscriber. All fees shall be payable on a calendar year basis in
advance. Delinquency in excess of ten days shall result in cancellation of the
permit or permits.
(Ord. 860608-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.11 ALARMS CONNECTED DIRECTLY TO POLICE STATION.
   (a)   The City presently has obtained State Alarm Systems, Inc., to provide
an alarm console system, using equipment for the purpose of providing a modern,
efficient system meeting the qualifications of this chapter and the needs of
the City and its residents. Provided that such system continues to meet all the
requirements of this chapter, the Company shall be granted a license to
continue this system on the premises of the Police Department for a period of
two years from the date of the passage of this chapter.
   (b)   At the end of two years from the date of the passage of this chapter,
the Safety Director, the Fire Chief and the Chief of Police, may review the
license and may invite other companies to provide information regarding their
system with a view towards constantly providing the highest quality and state-
of-the-art equipment on the market and consistent with the needs and
requirements of the City and its residents.
   (c)   Any license granted by the City for the placement of an alarm console
system on the premises of the Police Department shall provide the following:
      (1)   The alarm console shall be the most modern transistorized
instrument, of first quality, and capable of signalling an alarm by visual
display and audible tone, printer and three names and numbers of whom to call,
and any hazards to the Police or Fire Department.
      (2)    The alarm company shall provide the Police and/or Fire Department
with an updated list of connection and disconnections to the alarm console on a
continuing basis.
      (3)    Where more than one type of alarm is transmitted from one
location, the alarm company will provide that each of the different types are
easily distinguishable on the console at the Police Department.
            Example: Fire, breaking and entering, hold-up.
      (4)    The alarm company shall provide, install, and maintain the alarm
console and the associated equipment on a continuing basis so as to provide
efficient, dependable operation at no cost to the City.
      (5)    The alarm company shall consult with the Police Department
regarding the site of the installations and provide that the completed
installation be neat in appearance and lend itself to the work area of the
Department.
      (6)    The alarm company shall inform the Chief of Police or Fire Chief
of any change in the fee schedule no less than thirty days prior to the
effective date of such schedule change. The fees charged will be reasonable and
competitive with other comparable systems.
         (Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.12 GROUNDS FOR SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION.
   The following shall constitute grounds for suspension and revocation of any
permit issued under this chapter:
   (a)    The violation of any provisions of this chapter; or
   (b)    The failure to comply with standards or regulations adopted pursuant
to this chapter;
   (c)    Where any alarm business permittee, his agent or employee is charged
with a crime involving moral turpitude or where the character, reputation or
moral integrity of the permit holder or his employees is determined inimical to
public safety of the general welfare of the community; or
   (d)    Where an alarm system actuates excessive false alarms, in the
reasonable opinion of the Chief of Police or Chief of Fire. However, no
suspension and revocation may be issued under this subsection unless the
permittee has been issued a letter of warning by the Chief of Police or Chief
of Fire and has been given a reasonable period of time to take corrective
action, all as provided in Section
745.18.
   (e)    Where the applicant, or permittee, his employee or agent has
knowingly made any false, misleading or fraudulent statement of a material fact
in the application of the permit.
(Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.13 SUSPENDING AND REVOKING AUTHORITY.
   Any permit issued hereunder may be suspended by the Issuing Authority for
the grounds listed in Section
745.12.
(Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.14 PROCEDURE.
   (a)    The determination of the Issuing Authority with regard to matters of
suspension shall be appealable in the time and manner set forth in Section
745.07. The Issuing Authority in the case of such suspension, shall serve the
permittee with a Written Order of Suspension; which shall state the reasons for
such suspension, The Order shall be effective immediately if personally served,
or forty-eight hours after the same has been deposited in the course of
transmission in the United States Postal Service.
   (b)    Immediately upon such an Order becoming effective, the permittee
shall discontinue the use of any alarm system requiring a permit under this
chapter and cease all operations conducted under the authority of any permit
issued pursuant to this chapter. Failure to comply herewith shall be punishable
under Section
745.99.
(Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.15 REVOCATION.
   The suspension shall become a revocation fifteen days after the Order of
Suspension becomes effective unless the permittee files an appeal of the Order
of Suspension in the manner set forth in Section
745.07. Where an appeal is filed, the Order of Suspension shall be stayed
pending a determination thereon by the Appeals Board. Such suspension shall
become a revocation if the decision of the Appeals Board upholds the
suspension. The suspension shall be dissolved immediately if the decision of
the Appeals Board reverses the suspension.
(Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.16 SURRENDER OF PERMIT.
   If any permit is revoked pursuant to this chapter, the permittee shall
surrender such permit to the Issuing Authority.
(Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.17 EXCEPTION.
   An institution required by State or Federal law or regulation to maintain an
alarm system shall be exempt from the suspension and revocation sections of
this chapter but shall be subject to the penalties for violation of this
chapter as herein provided.
(Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.18 FALSE ALARMS.
   (a)    Each Department shall monitor the number of false alarms to which its
Department responds, keeping records of the same; such records shall indicate
the date of all false alarms to which the Department responds, the name and
address of the Alarm User of the system generating the false alarm, the time of
the false alarm, the weather conditions existing at the time of the false
alarm, and such additional information as deemed necessary by the Safety
Director. The Department shall also indicate in the false alarm records the
existence of mitigating or moderating circumstances relative to any false
alarms.
   (b)    If any false alarm produces two false alarms a month as the term
false alarm is defined in Section
745.01, in any twelve consecutive month period, the Issuing Authority shall
give written notice of the provisions of this section regarding false alarms by
certified mail or personal service to the Alarm User.
   (c)    If more than two false alarms in any twelve consecutive month period
are produced by any alarm system, a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall
be assessed the Alarm User for the third false alarm and a fee of fifty dollars
($50.00) for each false alarm thereafter in a twelve consecutive month period.
   (d)    The Issuing Authority may order an Alarm User to disconnect an alarm
system immediately so that signals are not emitted to the Police Department
either directly or indirectly if the alarm system has generated an excessive
number of false alarms. An excessive number of false alarms for the purpose of
this section is an accumulation of more than ten false alarms within a twelve
consecutive month period.
   (e)    Any person who fails to pay any charge for a false alarm as provided
in this section and which remains unpaid for thirty days after the date of
invoice for a false alarm or false alarms, shall be ordered by the Issuing
Authority to immediately disconnect the alarm system so that it does not signal
the Police or Fire Department either directly or indirectly. An alarm system
may be reconnected only if satisfactory evidence is provided to the Issuing
Authority that the alarm system has been repaired so that it does not emit
further false alarms, and upon payment of all delinquent charges assessed for
false alarms.
(Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.19 LIABILITY OF CITY.
   (a)    The issuance of any permit or permits in conjunction with this
chapter, shall not constitute acceptance by the City of any liability to
maintain any equipment, to answer alarms or for anything in connection
therewith. This governmental service shall not be acceptance by the City of any
liability, in contract, negligence or otherwise to provide any protection
whatsoever.
   (b)    The acceptance of any alarm system by the Chief of Police as provided
herein shall in no manner place upon the Police Department or the City any
additional liabilities than those legally incurred with the police functions.
(Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
745.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed
guilty of a minor misdemeanor. Each day of the violation may be a separate
violation of this chapter.
(Ord. 860603-49. Passed 6-3-86.)
CHAPTER 747
Sweepstakes Terminal Cafes
747.01    Purpose.
747.02    Applicability.
747.03    Definitions.
747.04    License required.
747.05    License fees.
747.06    License renewal.
747.07    Authority of the Zoning Officer.
747.08    Right of entry for inspection.
747.09    License application requirements.
747.10    Location.
747.11    Hours of operation.
747.12    Denial of sweepstakes terminal café license.
747.13    Appeal.
747.14    Regulations.
747.15    Severability.
747.99    Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Gambling - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
517
747.01 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this Chapter is to protect the public health, safety,
convenience, comfort, prosperity or general welfare of the residents by
establishing standards for licensing and regulation of computerized
sweepstakes/internet device cafes in the City of Salem. This chapter shall only
permit computerized sweepstakes/internet device cafes within C-2 General
Commercial, C-3 Central Commercial and M-2 Heavy Industrial Zoning Districts in
the City of Salem. This Chapter is designed to prevent safety and fire
hazzards, prevent disturbances, preserve the peaceful enjoyment of neighboring
establishments and residences, and preventing gambling and other criminal
behavior in the City of Salem.
(Ord. 111004-60. Passed 10-4-11.)
747.02  APPLICABILITY.
   This Chapter shall apply to the operation or computerized sweepstakes
terminals and internet cafes or establishments operating such terminals/
devices. This Chapter shall only apply to the operation of such terminals/
devices that are lawfully operating pursuant to the Ohio Revised Code and
nothing in this Chapter shall be construed to legalize, license or authorize
any operation of a device that is unlawful to operate pursuant to the Ohio
Revised Code. This chapter shall apply immediately to all devices, arcades and/
or internet cafes that commence operation after the date of enactment of this
Chapter. All arcades, internet cafes or establishments in existence at the time
of enactment of this Chapter shall come into compliance with all Sections of
this Chapter no later than thirty (30) days after enactment unless otherwise
stated herein.
(Ord. 111004-60. Passed 10- 4-11.)
747.03 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this Chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   (a)    Computerized Sweepstakes Device means any computer, machine, game or
apparatus which, upon the insertion of a coin, token, access number, magnetic
card, or similar object or upon the payment of anything of value, a product or
service is provided, and may be operated by the public generally for use as a
contest of skill, entertainment or amusement, whether or not registering a
score, and which in no way tends to promote or encourage gambling.
   (b)    Sweepstakes Terminal Café means any premises upon which any
computerized sweepstakes device is located for the use or entertainment of the
public, whether or not such premises have other business purposes of any nature
whatsoever.
   (c)    Owner means any person who possesses a pecuniary interest, either
directly or indirectly, of twenty-five percent (25%) or more in a Sweepstakes
Terminal Café.
   (d)    Operator means any person or persons having authority to control the
premises of a Sweepstakes Terminal Café.
   (e)    Franchise Holder means any person or persons who, through payment of
anything of value, buys, leases or through any other means is a franchise owner
of a Sweepstakes Terminal Café.
   (f)    Person means any natural person, firm, partnership, association,
corporation or any other form of business organization.
   (g)    Licensee means the person, persons or organization who signs an
application for a license and to whom such license is issued.
   (h)    Zoning Officer means the person responsible for enforcement of this
Chapter.
   (i)    Board means the Salem City Board of Zoning Appeals.
   (j)    Premises means the building or portion of building used to conduct or
operate a Sweepstakes Terminal Café.
   (k)    School means any education institution, private, secular, or
parochial, which offers instruction to preschool age children, elementary
through high school education, and/or colleges and universities of higher
education, technical schools, arts and music schools and other speciality
schools, and includes day care operations. (Ord. 111004-60. Passed 10-4-11.)
747.04 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)    No person shall conduct or operate a Sweepstakes Terminal Café
without having first obtained a Sweepstakes Terminal Café license as provided
in this chapter.
   (b)    No person shall display or allow the use of any Computerized
Sweepstakes Device without having first obtained a Sweepstakes Terminal Device
License as provided in this chapter. A separate license is required for each
Sweepstakes Terminal Device.
(Ord. 111004-60. Passed 10-4-11.)   
747.05 LICENSE FEES.
   (a)    There shall be a limit of four (4) Sweepstakes Terminal Café Licenses
issued in the City of Salem.
   (b)    A Sweepstakes Terminal Café license fee, payable to the City of Salem
at the time of application and annually thereafter shall be five thousand
dollars ($5,000.00) for each business location per year with such fee due on or
before January 1st of each year. The license fee shall be prorated for the
balance of any calendar year remaining from the date of application for new
applicants. Any existing Sweepstakes Terminal Cafes in operation at the time
this chapter is enacted shall have the license fee prorated from September 1st
to December 31st for the calendar year 2011. In the event that an application
is denied under this Chapter, one-half (½) of the application fee shall be
returned to the applicant. In the event that a license is revoked or suspended
hereunder, no portion of the license fee shall be returned.
   (c)    The fee for each Sweepstakes Terminal Device shall be $0 for each
device on the premises for each year or any part thereof ending on December 31
of each year.
   (d)    The fees, which are paid at the time of application, are not
refundable in any case. The license fee shall be paid for each device brought
to the facility before the device is put into use. For purposes of determining
licensing fees, each device that is operable by one or more person is a
separate device.
   (e)    Licenses issued under this Chapter shall not be transferable to any
other person, partnership, corporation, or other entity and the business may be
conducted only at the location for which the license is issued. The license
must be so placed as to be made conspicuously visible and shall list each
device with serial number.
   (f)    Failure to register any Sweepstakes Terminal Device before placement
on the premises is an unclassified misdemeanor and the operators shall each be
liable for a mandatory fine of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per device
for each day the device is not registered, and said fine shall not be reduced
or suspended.
(Ord. 111004-60. Passed 10-4-11.)
747.06 LICENSE RENEWAL.
   (a)    Each Sweepstakes Terminal Café License and each Sweepstakes Device
License must be renewed annually by January 1 of each year. Payment of fees
shall be made at the time of renewal, along with a written statement that shall
be filed with the Zoning Officer that the information listed on the original
application is still complete, accurate and truthful to the best knowledge of
all applicants, or a written statement shall be filed with the Zoning Officer
listing each and every item of information which has changed since the original
application. Such written statement shall be signed by the same person(s) who
signed the original application. The Zoning Officer may determine to accept
such statement and issue the license renewal requested, or he may determine to
enforce the procedure required for an original license.
   (b)    A Sweepstakes Terminal Café License shall not be renewed where an
owner, operator, employee or any other person involved with the operation is
not in compliance with the Salem Income Tax Department. In addition, failure to
be in compliance with Section
747.14 (f) shall result in a Sweepstakes Terminal License being suspended,
revoked or not renewed. (Ord. 111004-60. Passed 10-4-11.)
747.07 AUTHORITY OF THE ZONING OFFICER.
   (a)    Authority is hereby established and vested in the Zoning Officer to
consider applications for licenses under this chapter, conduct investigations
thereon and issue or deny issuance of such licenses based on the criteria set
forth in this chapter.
   (b)    Every owner, operator and employee of a Sweepstakes Terminal Café
shall provide a BCI (Ohio Bureau of Criminal Identification) background check
by an agency approved by the Zoning Officer and such person shall pay for the
costs associated with obtaining said BCI background check.
(Ord. 111004-60. Passed 10-4-11.)
747.08 RIGHT OF ENTRY FOR INSPECTION.
   (a)   The Salem City Fire Department shall make all fire safety inspections
relative the opening of the Sweepstakes Terminal Café and at normal intervals
during the operation of said Sweepstakes Terminal Café. The Salem City Police
Department shall make all criminal background investigations and any
inspections relative to Police Department requirements.
   (b)   The Sweepstakes Terminal Café shall be open to inspection and viewing
of operations by the Zoning Officer, Fire, Police and Health department
personnel, and/or any other city official, at all times that said café is open
for business. No operator shall fail to immediately permit entry to any such
officials. Failure to comply shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of
the Sweepstakes Terminal Café License.
(Ord. 111004-60. Passed 10-4-11.)
747.09  LICENSE APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   No person, partnership, corporation, or other entity shall operate or
conduct a Sweepstakes Terminal Café without first obtaining a license from the
City of Salem. Every person, partnership, corporation, organization or other
entity shall make an application in writing to said City which application
shall set forth, but not limited to:
      (1)   The name under which the business is to be conducted.
      (2)   The address location where the business is conducted, with a
description of the premises, including a scaled diagram of the floor plan which
shall include the dimensions and square footage for the area utilized for
placement of all Sweepstakes Terminal Devices, exit locations and sizes, window
locations an sizes, storage spaces, offices and the number and location of off-
street parking spaces.
      (3)   All address listings shall be a physical address in addition to any
Post Office Boxes.
      (4)   The name, address, date of birth and home/business/cell phone
numbers of any manager, supervisor, and all other employees.
      (5)   The name, address, date of birth and home/business/cell phone
number of the owner or owners of the entertainment devices.
      (6)   The name, address, date of birth, principal occupation and home/
business/cell phone number of every person with an interest in the business.
         If the business is conducted by:
         A.   A sole proprietorship: the name, home address, business/home/cell
phone number, date of birth and principal occupation of that individual.
         B.   A firm or partnership: the names, home addresses, business/home/
cell phone number, dates of birth, and principal occupations of each member of
the firm or partnership.
         C.   A corporation: the names, home addresses, business/home/cell
phone numbers, dates of birth and principal occupations of all directors,
officers and shareholders owing more than twenty-five percent (25%) of the
outstanding shares.
      (7)   A statement as to whether any owner has ever conducted Sweepstakes
Terminal Café and, if so, when, where and for how long.
      (8)   The name, description, model number and serial number of each
Sweepstakes Terminal Device on the premises and any other device on the
premises that is necessary to the operation of the Sweepstakes Terminal Device.
      (9)   A list of each separate prize that may be given out and each
separate dollar amount that may be given. The odds of winning any offered prize
or dollar amount awarded for the participation in any game, activity, program,
scheme or play, use or participation in any other activity or promotion in the
sweepstakes/internet café, whether or not the determination of the giving of
the thing of value or the delivery of the thing of value occurs totally within
the confines of the premises or requires some event, occurrence or happening at
another location.
      (10)   The name, address and business/cell phone number of any and all
persons, businesses or organizations that provide games, computer software,
equipment, or services or operate devices linked to the Sweepstakes Terminal
Device or to devices necessary to operate the entertainment devices, whether
any such provisions are sold, leased or licensed.
      (11)   The tax account number of the business from the City of Salem
Income Tax Department.
      (12)   The application is to include supporting documentation from a
Certified Independent Regulatory Compliance Test Laboratory that the software
performs in similar fashion as other permitted sweepstakes commercially offered
to the public and that the entries are drawn from a pre-created finite static
pool of entries with assigned values. To be certified, the Independent
Regulatory Compliance Testing Laboratory must be authorized to test regulated
gaming equipment by at least one state government gaming regulatory agency.
      (13)   A copy of the lease to the premises and/or any operating
agreement.
      (14)   Any other information as may be deemed necessary by the City of
Salem.
   (b)   The person, partnership, corporation, or other entity operating or
conducting the business shall have a continuing duty to inform the City of
Salem as to changes in the information required in this section. No person,
partnership, corporation or other entity shall operate or conduct a Sweepstakes
Terminal Café at any time unless the information on file with the City of Salem
is current and accurately reports the licensing information at the time of
operation.
   (c)   The Police Chief and Fire Chief shall endorse on each application
their approval or disapproval with reasons for any disapproval and return the
same within twenty (20) days of receiving the application. Within fourteen (14)
days of approval or disapproval by said Fire Chief and Police Chief and payment
of the license fees, the Zoning Officer shall either approve or deny the
license pursuant to this chapter.
   (d)   If an application is not approved, the City of Salem shall notify the
applicant in writing, with reasons for rejection.
   (e)   The City of Salem shall not issue a license to any person,
partnership, corporation or other entity if any of the persons with an interest
in the entity of if any of the employees of the business have been convicted of
a violation of a federal or state statue or of any local ordinance pertaining
to gambling or other crime of moral turpitude within five years (5) preceding
the application. All owners, employees and persons having an interest in the
business, as set forth in Section
747.09 (a)(5), shall consent to a criminal history check in accordance with
Section
747.07 (b).
   (f)   Each license issued under this chapter shall be permanently and
conspicuously displayed on the premises for which it is issued.
(Ord. 111004-60. Passed 10-4-11.)
747.10 LOCATION.
   (a)   A Sweepstakes Terminal Café shall be a permitted use within C-
2 General Commercial, C-3 Central Commercial, M-1 Light Industrial and M-
2 Heavy Industrial Zone Districts in the City of Salem. A Sweepstakes Terminal
Café shall not be permitted in any other Zone District in the City of Salem.
   (b)   A license shall not be granted to a Sweepstakes Terminal Café that
will conduct its business at a location that is within one thousand (1000) feet
from the boundaries of a parcel of real estate having situated on it a school,
public library, public playground, church or religious institution, or within
one thousand (1000) feet of any establishment that has been issued a liquor
permit by the State of Ohio.
   (c)   This section shall not apply to any Sweepstakes Terminal Café
locations in existence at the time of the passage of this ordinance, and shall
not apply to any duly licensed Sweepstakes Terminal Café locations in existence
at the time a school, public library, public playground, or any establishment
that has been issued a liquor permit by the State of Ohio moves within one
thousand (1000) feet of said Sweepstakes Terminal Café. However, any change in
ownership of the Sweepstakes Terminal Café or change in location will remove
said Sweepstakes Terminal Café from this exception. "Change in ownership" in
the case of a partnership or corporation for the purpose of this section means
more than fifty percent (50%) change in partners or shareholders from the
partners or shareholders owning the partnership or corporation as of the date
the school, public library, church, religious institution or public playground
moves within one thousand (1000) feet of said Sweepstakes Terminal Café.
(Ord. 111004-60. Passed 10-4-11.)
747.11 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   No operator of a Sweepstakes Terminal Café shall operate or permit the same
to be or remain open between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m. Monday
through Thursday, 2:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m. Friday and Saturday, and 12:00 a.m.
and 1:00 p.m. Sunday. No operator shall permit any person to operate any
Sweepstakes Terminal Device during any prohibited hours as referenced above.
(Ord. 111004-60. Passed 10-4-11.)
747.12 DENIAL OF SWEEPSTAKES TERMINAL CAFÉ LICENSE.
   A Sweepstakes Terminal Café License shall not be issued or renewed for any
business or premises for any of the following:
   (a)    Where the premises are located in any Zone District other than a C-
2 General Commercial, C-3 Central Commercial, M-1 Light Industrial or M-2 Heavy
Industrial.
   (b)    Where the premises do not specifically designate at least 30 gross
square feet of floor area for each Sweepstakes Terminal Device to be located
upon the premises, excluding areas used for other principal uses.
   (c)    Where the premises do not provide a minimum of thirty (30) off-street
parking places, or 1 parking space for every two Sweepstakes Terminal Devices,
whichever is greater. A Sweepstakes Terminal Café located within the C-
3 Central Commercial Zone District is exempt from this provision.
   (d)    Where the premises are located within one thousand (1000) feet of a
school, public library, church, religious institution or public playground or
any establishment that has been issued a liquor permit by the State of Ohio.
   (e)    Where it is determined that the premises or operation would be in
violation of any provision of the Ohio Basic Building Code, the Zoning Code,
Fire Code, State Health Code or any other pertinent provision of any local,
state or federal law.
   (f)    Where any of the owners or operators have been convicted within the
last five (5) years of any felony, a misdemeanor involving minors, a
misdemeanor involving moral turpitude or a crime of violence, or a misdemeanor
involving any gambling activity, controlled substance or alcoholic beverages.
   (g)    Where the applicant made a false statement on the application or in a
hearing concerning the license.
   (h)    Where the application failed to provide all the required information.
   (i)    Where the owner, operator and/or applicant fails to comply with all
terms and conditions under this chapter and all other applicable ordinances,
laws, rules and regulations.
      (Ord. 111004-60. Passed 10-4-11.)
747.13 APPEAL.
   If the Zoning Officer denies an application for a license or renewal of a
license, or revokes or suspends a license, the applicant or licensee may appeal
to the Salem City Board of Zoning Appeals. An appeal of the Zoning Officer's
decision may be taken to the Board of Zoning Appeals, within ten days from the
letter date denying an application/renewal or revoking/suspending a license, by
filing with the Zoning Officer, a written notice of appeal and stating grounds
thereon. A non-refundable fee of one hundred dollars($100.00) shall be paid to
the City of Salem for said appeal upon filing. The Board of Zoning Appeals
shall approve, modify or annul the Zoning Officer's decision, and the finding
of the Board shall be final.
(Ord. 111004- 60. Passed 10-4-11.)
747.14 REGULATIONS.
   In addition to any other regulations found in this chapter or these codified
ordinances, the following regulations are applicable to and shall govern and
control all licenses issued under this chapter:
   (a)    No licensee shall allow living quarters to exist with direct entry
into the premises.
   (b)    No licensee shall operate the Sweepstakes Terminal Café other than on
street level or on a level within three (3) feet of street level.
   (c)    No licensee shall allow any person, other than the owner or operator
twenty-one (21) years of age or older, who shall be readily identifiable, by
badge or other device, to be in control of the premises, nor to allow the
operator to be regularly situated in a place upon the premises other than a
place from which he/she has an unobstructed view of the entire portion of the
premises devoted to the operation of Sweepstakes Terminal Devices.
   (d)    No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years of age shall be
permitted in or on the premises in which is located a Sweepstakes Terminal
Café.
   (e)    The operator shall post in a conspicuous place in the room where the
Sweepstakes Terminal Devices are located in no less than twenty (20) point
type:
      (1)   Any and all sweepstakes rules and odds of winning.
      (2)   Each separate prize that may be given and each separate dollar
amount that might be given.
   (f)    The operator shall be required to maintain a list of every person
whom anything of value is given in connection with the Sweepstakes Terminal
Café. Said list shall contain the person's name, date of birth, current home
address, social security number and a description of the thing given, a stated
dollar value of the thing given, the date and time of the giving and, if an
entertainment device is involved in the circumstance of the giving, the serial
number or other identifying description of the device. If the dollar value
given for any single event for which there is a chance of winning is six
hundred dollars ($600.00) or more, the operator shall provide said list,
previously described, to the Salem Income Tax Department within fifteen (15)
days following the end of each quarter of each year. Failure to comply shall be
grounds for suspension or revocation of the Sweepstakes Terminal Café License.
   (g)    All Sweepstakes Terminal Devices shall be located on the premises in
conformity with the floor plan filed with the application for the license and
shall:
      (1)   Not impair ingress or egress to the premises.
      (2)   Not interfere with free and unfettered passage through the
premises.
      (3)   Be located so that the back of any Sweepstakes Terminal Device is
not exposed to a window.
      (4)   Be so located so to permit a clear and complete view of the
interior of the premises immediately upon entry. In addition, front windows
shall not be darkened or covered to impair the complete view of the interior
from the exterior of the premises.
   (h)    No operator shall permit or fail to take active steps to eliminate
the activities set forth in this section from occurring on the premises. Every
operator shall have a duty to diligently pursue enforcement of this section.
Failure to take action or control the following may allow the Salem Chief of
Police to order full time security personnel, at the expense of the operator,
to be on duty. No licensee shall:
      (1)   Permit any indecent, immoral or disorderly conduct, upon the
premises.
      (2)   Permit the premises to be a gathering place for disorderly persons
of any type.
      (3)   Permit gambling in any form or the possession or use of gambling
paraphernalia on the premises.
      (4)   Permit alcohol beverages or the consumption of alcohol beverages on
the premises.
      (5)   Permit the possession or use of any unlawful drug, narcotic or
controlled substance on the premises.
      (6)   Permit the public street, sidewalks, alleys or walkways in the
immediate vicinity of any entrance or exit to the premises to be littered.
      (7)   Permit the sidewalks to become obstructed in any manner so that
pedestrian traffic is hindered.
      (8)   Permit any Sweepstakes Terminal Device in the premises to be
operated at any time the premises is not open for business, or permit the
entrance to be locked at any time the premises are open for business.
      (9)   Permit the premises to become overcrowded so as to constitute a
hazard to the health or safety of persons inside or to be in violation of any
of the City's relevant code provisions.
      (10)   Permit any Sweepstakes Terminal Device to be offered to the public
for operation unless fully operable and in safe operating condition.
         (Ord. 111004-60. Passed 10-4-11.)
747.15 SEVERABILITY.
   Should a section, provision, clause, phrase or sentence of this chapter be
declared, by a court of competent jurisdiction, to be invalid, that decision
shall not effect the validity of this chapter as a whole or any part thereof,
other than the part so declared to be invalid.
(Ord. 111004-60. Passed 10-4-11.)
747.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the First Degree and shall not be fined more than one hundred
and fifty dollars ($150.00) for each offense, said fine shall not be reduced or
suspended. Each day a violation occurs or continues to occur shall constitute a
separate offense. In addition to the penalties set forth herein, the license
for the Sweepstakes Terminal Café shall be permanently revoked.
(Ord. 111004-60. Passed 10-4-11.)
CHAPTER 749
Video Service Providers
749.01    Fee.
749.01 FEE.
   (a)   Council hereby establishes a VSP Fee that is calculated by applying a
VSP Fee Percentage of three percent (3%) to the video service provider's gross
revenues as defined in Section 1332.32(B) of the Video Law. For purposes of
calculating the VSP Fee, the provider's gross revenues shall include
advertising revenues in accordance with Section 1332.23(B)(2)(g) of the Video
Law. The VSP Fee Percentage and Video Law gross revenues definition, as
modified in this Ordinance, shall apply equally to all video service providers
and cable television operators providing video service in the City.
   (b)   The VSP Fee shall be paid by each video service provider providing
service in the City on a quarterly basis but not sooner than forty-five (45)
days nor later than sixty (60) days after the end of each calendar quarter.
   (c)   The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed to provide any video
service provider with notice of the VSP Fee Percentage and gross revenues
definition as determined by this Council above, which notice shall be given by
certified mail, upon receipt of notice from such video service provider that it
will begin providing video service in the City pursuant to a state-issued video
service authorization.
(Ord. 110504-17. Passed 7-5-11.)
CHAPTER 750
Commercial Indoor Shooting Ranges
750.01   Definitions.
750.02   Location.
750.03   License required.
750.04   License application.
750.05   Construction standards.
750.06   Permit requirements.
750.07   Rules and regulations.
750.08   Permit revocation, suspension or denial.
750.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Discharge of firearms - see GEN. OFF.
549.10
Private residential indoor shooting ranges - see P. & Z. Ch.
1188
750.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   "Commercial Indoor Shooting Range" means any indoor area within
established Commercial or Industrial zoned areas which is established for the
purpose of pistol and/or rifle shooting, whether or not said shooting range is
operated for profit and whether or not existing at the time of passage of this
ordinance or established thereafter.
   (b)   "Firearms" means any weapon expelling a projectile(s) by the action of
an explosive. (Ord. 140401-20. Passed 6-3-14.)
750.02  LOCATION.
   Indoor Shooting Ranges may not be located within 100 yards of a school, day
care, church or playground. (Ord. 140401-20. Passed 6-3-14.)
750.03 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall construct, modify, restore or otherwise alter a Commercial
Indoor Shooting Range unless the person shall first obtain a license therefore
from the Planning and Zoning Officer. The license shall be issued subject to
the rules and regulations set forth in this chapter.
(Ord. 140401-20. Passed 6-3-14.)
750.04 LICENSE APPLICATION.
   (a)   No person, partnership, corporation, or other entity shall operate an
indoor shooting range without first obtaining a license from the City of Salem.
Every person, partnership, corporation, organization or other entity shall make
an application in writing to said City which application shall set forth, but
not limited to:
      (1)   The name under which the business is to be conducted.
      (2)   The address location where the business is conducted.
      (3)   The application is to include supporting documentation from a
professional engineer or architect licensed by the State of Ohio attesting that
the proposed shooting range meets or exceeds the standards set out in the
construction standards detailed in Section
750.05 .
   (b)   If the business is conducted by:
      (1)   A sole proprietorship: the name, home address, business/home/cell
phone number, date of birth and principal occupation of that individual.
      (2)   A firm or partnership: the names, home addresses, business/home/
cell phone number, dates of birth, and principal occupations of each member of
the firm or partnership.
      (3)   A corporation: the names, home addresses, business/home/cell phone
numbers, dates of birth and principal occupations of all directors, officers
and shareholders owning more than twenty-five percent (25%) of the outstanding
shares.
   (c)   The person, partnership, corporation, or other entity operating or
conducting the business shall have a continuing duty to inform the City of
Salem as to changes in the information required in this section. The license
issued hereunder is nontransferable without prior approval of the City of Salem
and no person, partnership, corporation or other entity shall operate an indoor
shooting range at any time unless the information on file with the City of
Salem is current and accurately reports the licensing information at the time
of operation.
   (d)   If an application is not approved, the City of Salem shall notify the
applicant in writing, with reasons for rejection.
   (e)   Each license issued under this chapter shall be permanently and
conspicuously displayed on the premises for which it is issued.
   
   (f)   If a person who has been convicted of a felony shall have any
ownership interest in any indoor shooting range as set out in the Codified
Ordinances of the City of Salem.
(Ord. 140401-20. Passed 6-3-14.)
750.05  CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS.
   Any application for a license for any indoor shooting range must conform to
the most current standards set out in The Range Source Book, published by the
National Rifle Association (NRA) and as such standards may hereafter be
modified. However such standards shall never be less than the minimum standards
as set forth below.
Indoor Range Design Specifications
   Approval of a license for the installation of an indoor shooting range will
be dependent on the applicant providing plans and specifications for such range
as prepared by professional engineer or architect (licensed by the State of
Ohio). The plans and specifications should consider the type of use by the
facility shall meet or exceed the following minimum standards.
   (a)   Backstops and Bullet Traps
      (1)   Steel bullet traps
         A.   Angle of deflection will be 42 degrees from horizontal.
      (2)   Granular rubber traps
         A.   Granular rubber trap for capturing jacketed, semi-jacketed and
non-jacketed, shot and slug projectiles with velocities 600 feet per second
(FPS) (183 meters) to .308/7.62 mm grade, certified up to 3600 foot-pounds(4881
joules) of impact. Granular rubber traps capture projectiles fired from oblique
angles and point-blank range without back-splatter or ricochet.
            1.   Trap Assembly includes a support frame inclined relative to
the direction of Incoming projectiles.
            2.   Support frame includes an inclined support surface fabricated
from 10 gauge Steel and supported by a steel truss structure arranged and
configured to properly support the granular rubber media.
            3.   Rubber granulate material fills the area within the support
frame.
            4.   Ballistic rubber bloc forms the front edge of the trap
assembly to contain the rubber granulate fill and capture, rather than
redirect, errant rounds.
            5.   A hopper located above the target region of the trap provides
a supplemental volume of rubber granulate to maintain a constant depth of
material. The front facing of the hopper is constructed of AR 500 steel and
covered with 2 inch (51mm) thick ballistic rubber to provide ballistic
protection and capture errant shots. To accommodate lower ceiling height, trap
assembly will be complete without hopper components.
      (3)   Thickness.
         A.   Backstop of armor plate 300 Brinell Hardness Number (BHN) will be
minimum 10 mm (.375 inch) in thickness.
         B.   Backstop of 440 BHN steel plate will be minimum 6 mm (.25 inch)
in thickness.
         C.   Backstop of 500 BHN steel plate will be minimum 6 mm (.25 inch)
in thickness.
      (4)   Anchorage.
         A.   Steel plates anchored by concrete or masonry must be anchored by
expansion bolts or toggle bolts.
         B.   Joints and edge lines shall be backed with continuous ½ inch
plate no less than 4 inches wide.
         C.   Expansion bolts penetrate concrete not less than 2 inches.
         D.   Joints must be butted flush and smooth. There shall be no
horizontal joints in any steel plate work.
         E.   Steel plates joined at and supported on structural steel supports
must be spot welded to steel supports not more than 6 inches on center.
   (b)   Baffles/Deflectors/Shields.
      (1)   Baffles.
         A.   Baffles must extend the entire width of the range and downward to
cover or protect vulnerable ceiling areas or range fixtures.
         B.   Ceilings, which may also serve as floors for inhabited space
above the range, must be impenetrable by bullets and ricochets.
         C.   Baffles are required to have steel portion covered by a minimum
of 1 inch of soft wood or ballistic rubber adhered directly to the surface of
the steel.
         D.   Baffles must be installed at a 25 to 30 degree angle as measured
from the horizontal plane of the ceiling.
      (2)   Deflectors. Deflectors will be installed vertically or horizontally
to redirect wide angle shots into the backstop area and will be installed at a
25 degree angle either to the wall surface or floor, or be designed with an
approved ballistic rubber facing for encapsulating rounds on impact.
      (3)   Shields.
         A.   Shields are to be installed above the firing line, to protect
ceiling areas.
         B.   Shields are to extend the entire width of the range and 12 feet
forward of the firing line.
   (c)   Walls, Ceilings and Floors - Walls, ceilings and floors of an indoor
range facility must be impenetrable.
      (1)   Walls. Walls must be either poured-in-place concrete, precast
concrete or dense masonry block (common solid cinder block should be used in
place of the hollow-core block to better withstand glancing strikes of an
occasional direct hit without sustaining much damage).
      (2)   Floors. Floors must be either poured-in-place concrete, precast
concrete or dense masonry block (common solid cinder block should be used in
place of the hollow-core block to better withstand glancing strikes of an
occasional direct hit without sustaining much damage).
   (d)   Shooting Booths – Shooting booths should provide an impenetrable
barrier between shooters, restrict the travel of expended brass and act as a
spray shield when revolvers are used.
      (1)   Booth panels must be impenetrable by the bullet from any firearm
used on the range. (Panel must be capable of withstanding the impact of a
bullet fired at any angle to the surface and at point blank range. Recommended
construction of booth panels is for 10 gauge steel plate covered with a nominal
2 inches of soft wood.
      (2)   Booth panels must reduce muzzle blast effects on shooters and range
personnel, including the shooter occupying a booth. This can be accomplished by
special acoustical material.
      (3)   Booth panels must not restrict airflow.
      (4)   Booth panels must not restrict visibility of the firing line by the
range officer.
      (5)   Booth panels must extend from floor to at least 6 feet high,
preferably to the ceiling.
   (e)   Target Carriers – All indoor shooting ranges shall have a target
transport system in order to alleviate manual target retrieval
   (f)   Sound Control – Sound control on indoor ranges include two distinct
components, sound levels within the range, and sound levels in adjoining,
occupied rooms.
      (1)   To minimize amplification of sound within the range by reflection,
acoustical material must be applied to walls and ceiling.
      (2)   To reduce transmission of sound to adjoining rooms, doors, windows,
ceilings and walls should have air leaks sealed with air-tight insulation.
Ventilation and heating ducts should be lined with acoustical material.
   (g)   Ventilation and Filtering Systems – The ventilation system design
should be what best addresses the protection of workers, the location and type
of climate conditions.
      (1)   Ventilation systems must comply with the OSHA Lead Standard for
General Industry 29 CFR 1910.1025, and other state and local building codes,
laws and regulations.
         (Ord. 140401-20. Passed 6-3-14.)
750.06  PERMIT REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   No person shall open, conduct or operate a Commercial Indoor Shooting
Range unless the person shall first obtain a permit therefore from the Planning
and Zoning Officer.
   (b)   Upon application for a Commercial Indoor Shooting Range, there shall
be filed with the Zoning Officer, design plans which bear the stamp of approval
and signature of professional engineer or architect which is licensed in the
State of Ohio certifying that the Commercial Indoor Shooting Range meet the
minimum construction standards and design specifications as set out in Section
750.05 .
   (c)   The fee for a Commercial Indoor Shooting Range Permit, shall be as set
forth on the fee schedule posted in the Salem Planning & Zoning Office. The
permit fee shall be on an annual basis and is not refundable. Permits issued
hereunder are nontransferable.
   (d)   In addition to the fee stated in (b) above, the applicant will be
responsible for the cost to the City of Salem to conduct plan reviews and any
inspections at the completion of the construction, modification or restoration
of the indoor shooting range.
   (e)   Applications for a Commercial Indoor Shooting Range shall be made to
the City of Salem, Zoning Office and shall include, but not limited to, the
following information:
      (1)   Site Plan, signed by a surveyor, architect or engineer, registered
by the State of Ohio, to scale showing the location of all the components of
the proposed Commercial Indoor Shooting Range and the locations of all existing
structures, buildings, property lines, along with distances and
      (2)   Elevation drawings of the site to scale showing the height, design,
and configuration of the proposed Commercial Indoor Shooting Range and the
distance to all existing structures, buildings, property lines.
         (Ord. 140401-20. Passed 6-3-14.)
750.07 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Safety Service Director, upon the recommendation of the Chief of Police,
may promulgate and enforce reasonable rules and regulations to carry out the
intent of this chapter, all such rules must be posted by the licensed operator
in a conspicuous place at the indoor firing range.
(Ord. 140401-20. Passed 6-3-14.)
750.08 PERMIT REVOCATION, SUSPENSION OR DENIAL.
   (a)    The Planning & Zoning Officer shall refuse to issue or renew an
indoor shooting range permit or may revoke or suspend such permit where he
finds that:
      (1)    A section of this chapter was violated upon the establishment
premises;
      (2)    A violation of any section of the Ohio Revised Code or a City of
Salem Code was committed upon the establishment premises, or by any employee on
the premises;
      (3)    A material misrepresentation was made upon the application; or
      (4)    Any law enforcement officer or code inspector was refused
permission to inspect the indoor shooting range premises or any portion of its
operation during the scheduled hours of operation.
   (b)    A person shall be notified in writing as to the reason why a permit
is revoked, suspended or denied. An appeal of the decision of the Planning &
Zoning Officer may be taken to the Salem Board of Zoning Appeals in accordance
with Chapter
1139 .
(Ord. 140401-20. Passed 6-3-14.)
750.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the fourth degree. The imposition of penalties herein prescribed shall not
preclude the Director of Law from instituting an appropriate action or
proceeding to prevent unlawful operation of an indoor shooting range or
performance of unlawful activity on or about any indoor shooting range
premises. (Ord. 140401-20. Passed 6-3-14.)
CHAPTER 751
Food Trucks
751.01    Definitions.
751.02    Food truck permit.
751.03    License and permit requirements for operation.
751.04    General requirements.
751.05    Operation in right-of-way; public property.
751.06    Products for sale.
751.07    Restrictions on hours of operation.
751.99    Penalty.
751.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "Food" shall mean a raw, cooked or processed edible substance, ice,
beverage or ingredient used or intended for use or for sale in whole or part
for human consumption.
   (b)    "Food truck" means a vehicle or vehicle and trailer propelled by an
engine or other means which has been specifically designed or used for mobile
food vending.
   (c)    "Food truck permit" shall mean the permit issued by the Salem City
Health Department , pursuant to this Chapter.
   (d)    "Mobile Food Service License" and "Mobile Food Establishment License"
means the official document issued by any Board of Health in the State of Ohio
possessing the appropriate licensing authority which allows the operation of a
food truck in Columbiana County and the City of Salem.
(Ord. 240604-38. Passed 7-2-24.)
751.02 FOOD TRUCK PERMIT.
   Food truck operators shall apply annually for and receive a Food Truck
Permit through the Salem City Health Department prior to any operation within
the City of Salem. The fees for Food Truck Permits shall be proposed annually
by the Mayor and approved by Council. Failure of the Mayor to propose a fee
schedule or Council to approve a schedule shall result in the previous fee
schedule remaining in place until otherwise modified.
(Ord. 240604-38. Passed 7-2-24.)
751.03 LICENSE AND PERMIT REQUIREMENTS FOR OPERATION.
   (a)    No person shall offer for sale any food from any food truck within
the City without a current and valid Mobile Food Service or Mobile Food
Establishment License.
   (b)    A Mobile Food Service or Mobile Food Establishment License must be
clearly and conspicuously displayed on the food truck during all times of
operation for inspection by the City of Salem Board of Health.
   (c)    A Food Truck Permit must also be obtained by the operator of any food
truck before the food truck may operate within the City. Fees for permits may
be found on the City of Salem website.
   (d)    All food trucks shall be subject to inspection during operation by
the Environmental Health Officer for compliance with local, and state health
and fire code laws and regulations. All food trucks shall be required to notify
the Salem Fire Department of when and where they will be operating in the City
and be subject to inspection by the Salem Fire Department prior to operation.
   (e)    All food trucks shall comply with inspection requirements, including
the possibility of random inspections, as set forth in the permit packet issued
by the City.
(Ord. 240604-38. Passed 7-2-24.)
751.04 GENERAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    All food trucks operating in the City of Salem must keep the
surrounding area immediately adjacent to the food truck clean and must dispose
of all waste generated from the operation.
   (b)    All food trucks must be constructed to internally store and contain
all sewage and wastewater for proper disposal and to prevent groundwater
contamination. There shall be no discharge of any sewage and wastewater onto
the ground or into any storm water or sanitary sewers within the City.
   (c)    No food truck shall utilize loud speakers or other noise making
devices in such a way as to create a nuisance, or in violation of the City's
ordinances.
(Ord. 240604-38. Passed 7-2-24.)
751.05 OPERATION IN RIGHT-OF-WAY; PUBLIC PROPERTY
   (a)    Food truck operators are prohibited from parking or operating in the
public right-of-way or upon any City street unless in conjunction with a
community event and specifically authorized to do so.
   (b)    Food truck operators are prohibited from parking or operating on
public property, including public parks, without prior written authorization
from the City of Salem Parks Department for park property or the City Safety
Service Director, or his or her designee, for all other public property. (Ord.
240604-38. Passed 7-2-24.)
751.06 PRODUCTS FOR SALE.
   Food trucks shall only offer for sale food as defined above.
(Ord. 240604-38. Passed 7-2-24.)
751.07 RESTRICTIONS ON HOURS OF OPERATION.
   (a)    Food trucks may not operate between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 7:30
a.m.
(Ord. 240604-38. Passed 7-2-24.)
751.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this Chapter is guilty of a fourth degree
misdemeanor.
(Ord. 240604-38. Passed 7-2-24.)

CHAPTER 901
Sidewalks

901.12   Failure to comply with notice.
